en.question: A major leak has occurred in the service line, so you put the brakes on. The service air will escape and cause:

options.A: Transmission to fail
options.B: Trailer emergency brakes to come on.
options.C: Engine to overheat

en.description: If there's a major leak in the service line, the service air escapes and causes the emergency trailer brakes to activate.

en.question: What do glad hands usually connect?

options.A: Transmission cables for gear shifting
options.B: Hydraulic fluid lines for brake cooling.
options.C: Service and emergency air lines from the vehicle to the trailer.

en.description: Glad hands are used to connect the service and emergency air lines between the truck and trailer to control the trailer's brakes.

en.question: When you have supplied air to the trailer, you should check that the air lines are not crossed and that the brakes are functioning. You can do this by:

options.A: Checking the radio for static changes.
options.B: Flipping the light switches inside the cab.
options.C: Applying and releasing the trailer brakes and listening for the sound of the brake.

en.description: After supplying air to the trailer, apply and release the trailer brakes and listen for the sound. This confirms the lines are correctly connected and the brakes function.

en.question: How much room should there be between the top and bottom parts of the fifth wheel after coupling?

options.A: 2 inches
options.B: 1/2 inch
options.C: None.

en.description: There should be no space between the top and bottom of the fifth wheel after coupling. Any gap may indicate an improper or unsafe connection.

en.question: To unlock the fifth wheel, you need to move the locking lever to the ___ position.

options.A: Horizontal
options.B: Open
options.C: Locked

en.description: To release the trailer from the truck, move the fifth wheel locking lever to the 'Open' position.

en.question: To prevent a rollover, a driver can do two things: 1) Drive slowly when turning, and 2)

options.A: Keep the cargo as close to the ground as possible.
options.B: Drive in the middle of the road
options.C: Fill the fuel tank to the top before turning.

en.description: Prevent rollovers by slowing down in turns and keeping your load low to maintain a stable center of gravity.

en.question: You are coupling a truck to the semitrailer and have connected the air lines. Before reversing under the trailer, what should you do?

options.A: Check the tire pressure on the truck.
options.B: Supply air to the trailer system, then pull out the air supply knob.
options.C: Raise the landing gear completely.

en.description: Before backing under the trailer, supply air to the trailer and pull the air supply knob to ensure the brakes are functioning properly.

en.question: When you're preparing to reverse and go under a semitrailer, you should line up:

options.A: Align the truck's headlights with the trailer's tail lights.
options.B: Directly in front of the trailer.
options.C: About a truck-length away from the trailer.

en.description: To safely back under a semitrailer, line up the truck directly in front of the trailer for proper alignment.

en.question: When backing a truck under a trailer you should:

options.A: Use a spotter who signals you from the driver's side mirror.
options.B: Make sure your radio is turned up loud to hear the trailer better.
options.C: Always use the lowest reverse gear.

en.description: Always use the lowest reverse gear to move slowly and safely when backing under a trailer.

en.question: At what angle should the seals with the couplers be pressed together when connecting the glad hands?

options.A: 120 degrees
options.B: 90 degrees.
options.C: 75 degrees

en.description: Glad hands should be connected at a 90-degree angle to ensure a secure and sealed air connection.

en.question: To prevent a truck from rolling over, a driver needs to do two things: 1) drive slowly when turning, and 2)

options.A: Keep the cargo as close to the ground as possible.
options.B: Drive with the windows open to reduce air resistance.
options.C: Load the vehicle to its maximum capacity.

en.description: Driving slowly during turns and keeping cargo low helps maintain balance and prevent rollovers.

en.question: When the front trailer supports are up and the trailer rests on the truck, make sure:

options.A: There is enough clearance between the tractor frame and the landing gear.
options.B: There is enough clearance between the top of the tractor tires and nose of the trailer.
options.C: Both options are correct.

en.description: You must ensure both clearances—between the tractor frame and landing gear, and between the top of the tractor tires and trailer nose—are sufficient to avoid damage.

en.question: The truck protection valve will shut off, and the emergency brakes on the trailer will activate if there's a big leak in the _ brake line.

options.A: Cooling
options.B: Emergency
options.C: Fuel

en.description: If there's a major leak in the emergency brake line, the truck protection valve shuts off and activates the trailer’s emergency brakes.

en.question: What can make brakes get worse or stop working?

options.A: Use of the service brakes too much
options.B: Brakes that aren't set right
options.C: Not using the engine brakes enough

en.description: Brakes can stop working well if you use them too much, they're not adjusted correctly, or you don't use engine braking enough. So, all of these reasons can make brakes go bad.

en.question: In controlled braking, you press the brakes as hard as possible without making the wheels stop turning and _

options.A: Turn off the engine immediately.
options.B: Accelerate a little.
options.C: Maintain the vehicle traveling in a straight line.

en.description: When using controlled braking, you press on the brake really hard but make sure your wheels don't stop spinning completely. This way, you can keep your vehicle moving straight without it sliding or going off course.

en.question: What happens when you step on the brake pedal?

options.A: The brake pedal becomes harder to press.
options.B: Pressurized air flows to the brake chambers.
options.C: The vehicle automatically speeds up.

en.description: When you push the brake pedal, air that's under pressure goes to the brakes and makes them work. This is how the vehicle slows down or stops.

en.question: How can you figure out if your vehicle has a system that stops the brakes from locking up (ABS)?

options.A: Look for an "ABS" badge or sticker on the brake fluid reservoir.
options.B: Check to see if the vehicle was manufactured after 1998.
options.C: Check under the hood for a uniquely shaped ABS control module.

en.description: To know if your vehicle has an anti-lock braking system (ABS), check if it was made after 1998. Cars built after that year usually have ABS.

en.question: When doing the final check, how can you tell if the spring brakes activate when the air pressure gets too low?

options.A: Check the dashboard for a specific light indicator while driving at a low speed.
options.B: Park on level ground, chock the wheels, release the parking brake when you have enough air pressure, shut the engine off, and repeatedly press on and off the brake pedal until the warning light comes on
options.C: Drive around the block until the air pressure warning light activates.

en.description: To check if the spring brakes activate at the right air pressure level, do this: Find flat ground and put blocks on the wheels. With enough air in the system, turn off the parking brake, then the engine. Push the brake pedal several times until you see a warning light.

en.question: How can you make sure the low air pressure warning light in your vehicle is working properly?

options.A: Reduce air pressure below 60 psi by pumping the brakes with the engine off.
options.B: Pump the brakes while the engine is turned on.
options.C: Fill the tires with water to check pressure stability.
options.D: Completely remove the air compressor to check.

en.description: To check if the low air pressure warning in your vehicle works, do this: Turn off the engine and then hit the brakes a few times until the air pressure drops below 60 psi. This should make the warning go off if it's working right.

en.question: What's the best method to fix a skid caused by the drive wheels locking up?

options.A: Pump the brakes while the engine is turned on.
options.B: Stop braking, turn quickly, and countersteer
options.C: Accelerate and steer straight ahead.

en.description: When your vehicle's drive wheels lock up and skid while braking, the best thing to do is to stop braking, turn quickly in the direction you want to go, and then steer back to straighten out.

en.question: If you're driving a vehicle that has a front brake limiting valve, you should __

options.A: Only use it in heavy traffic conditions.
options.B: Always set it to normal mode
options.C: Switch it off during rain.

en.description: If your truck has a special control that changes how the front brakes work, you should always keep this control in the normal setting. This means you shouldn't mess with it or switch it to a different mode. Keeping it normal helps make sure your truck stops the right way and keeps you safe on the road.

en.question: The service brake system uses _

options.A: The air conditioning system to reduce speed.
options.B: The brakes when the driver presses on the foot brake pedal.
options.C: The vehicle's sound system to signal slowing down.

en.description: When you press the foot brake pedal in a vehicle, you're using the service braking system. This helps to slow down or stop the vehicle.

en.question: Why do you have to demonstrate your knowledge by passing the exam on air brakes?

options.A: If not, you will have to get a restricted CDL.
options.B: To ensure your vehicle doesn't use too much fuel.
options.C: To make sure you can drive safely in the rain.
options.D: Air brakes are on all trucks.

en.description: Taking the air brakes exam is a must because if you don't, you'll end up with a limited version of the commercial driver's license, which means you can't drive all the vehicles you might want to.

en.question: Can you leave your truck without putting on the parking brakes or chocking the wheels first?

options.A: Yes, if it's parked on a flat surface.
options.B: Yes, if the engine is still running.
options.C: No, never.

en.description: No, you should never leave your truck without making sure it's safely parked. This means either putting on the parking brakes or using blocks to stop the wheels from moving. It's important to do this so your truck doesn't roll away.

en.question: What is true about a dual air brake system?

options.A: Only one set of brake controls is used.
options.B: One system controls the front axle and another the rear
options.C: One is called the "primary" system and one is called the "secondary" system.

en.description: A dual air brake system for big trucks has two main parts. One part is called "primary" and the other is "secondary." The primary part usually takes care of the back wheels, and the secondary part handles the front. But there's just one set of controls for the driver to use. So, the correct answer is that all these statements are true.

en.question: Can you adjust the automatic slack adjuster manually?

options.A: Never adjust it manually.
options.B: Adjust it after every long trip.
options.C: When it's not working properly.
options.D: Always adjust it in every inspection.

en.description: Only adjust the automatic slack adjuster yourself if it's not working right. This means, if you notice it's not adjusting the brakes like it should, then you can manually fix it.

en.question: What are spring brakes?

options.A: They are special brakes used only for parking on steep hills.
options.B: If the air brakes lose pressure, the spring brakes will activate to stop the vehicle.
options.C: They are advanced brakes that automatically adjust based on the weight of the cargo.
options.D: They are a type brakes designed to work more effectively during the Spring season

en.description: Spring brakes are like emergency helpers for big trucks. If the truck's main brake system, which works with air pressure, fails or loses power, these spring brakes automatically kick in to stop the truck. This helps prevent accidents.

en.question: If the braking system fails, the emergency braking system can use __ to stop the vehicle.

options.A: Parts of the service and parking brakes
options.B: Gravity and wheel friction
options.C: The vehicle's momentum

en.description: If the main brakes don't work, the emergency brakes can use parts of the normal and parking brakes to stop the truck.

en.question: The maximum permissible rate of air pressure loss in the braking system of a vehicle when the brakes are applied and the engine is off is__

options.A: 5 psi for single and 6 psi for combination
options.B: 2 psi for single and 3 psi for combination.
options.C: 5 psi for single and 6 psi for combination
options.D: 4 psi for single and 5 psi for combination.

en.description: The right answer is: 2 psi for a single vehicle and 3 psi for a vehicle that's pulling another one.

en.question: Air brakes work by using___ to operate the brakes.

options.A: Hydraulic fluid
options.B: Carbon dioxide
options.C: Pressurized air

en.description: Air brakes in big trucks work with pressurized air. This means they use air that's pushed together tightly to make the brakes stop the truck.

en.question: What does the ABS do?

options.A: Regulates the engine speed.
options.B: Makes the vehicle go faster.
options.C: Turns on when the wheels are about to lock up
options.D: Always decreases the stopping distance significantly.

en.description: ABS helps stop your vehicle without the wheels getting stuck and skidding. When it senses the wheels might lock up and cause a skid, it quickly pumps the brakes to keep the wheels rolling and give you better control.

en.question: When you use the parking brakes, _.

options.A: Locking the wheels immediately.
options.B: Taking air out of the brake chambers.
options.C: Releasing air from the tires.

en.description: When you use the parking brakes, it means you are letting air out of the brake parts that help stop the truck. This helps keep the truck from moving when parked.

en.question: Which one of these is NOT included in the air brake system?

options.A: Service brake system
options.B: Emergency brake system
options.C: Radio signal system

en.description: The air brake system helps big vehicles like trucks stop safely. But the radio signal system does not help with stopping the vehicle, so it's not part of the air brake system.

en.question: How do you make sure the slack adjusters in your truck are okay?

options.A: Use gloves and pull hard on each slack adjuster that you can reach.
options.B: Check the vehicles oil level.
options.C: Inspect the tire tread depth.

en.description: To check the slack adjusters in your truck, wear gloves and pull hard on each one you can reach.

en.question: The truck protection valve___

options.A: Supplies the braking system with air.
options.B: Automatically closes if the air supply falls below a particular threshold.
options.C: Can be closed by applying the parking brakes.

en.description: The truck protection valve does three things: it gives air to the brakes, closes by itself if air gets too low, and can be shut off when you use the parking brake. So the answer is 'All of the above.'

en.question: What does the S-cam do?

options.A: Helps to cool down the engine faster
options.B: Increases fuel efficiency by optimizing air flow.
options.C: Push the brake shoes against the inside of braking drum

en.description: We need the S-cam to push the brake pads against the inside of the brake drum. This helps the vehicle to stop when you press the brake pedal.

en.question: If you want to stop as quickly as you can when driving a vehicle without anti-lock brakes, the most effective technique is _

options.A: The controlled braking technique
options.B: The stab braking technique
options.C: Both techiques will help stop the vehicle quickly.

en.description: To stop quickly in a vehicle without anti-lock brakes, use both techniques mentioned. These methods help the vehicle stop faster.

en.question: How thick do the drum linings have to be according to the government rules on air brakes?

options.A: 1/8 inch
options.B: 1/4 inch
options.C: 3/8 inch

en.description: For air brakes on trucks, there is a rule about how thick the brake pads need to be. They can't be thinner than 1/4 inch. This is important for safety.

en.question: Which of the following statements about a dual air brake system is correct?

options.A: Each system operates independently in case of a failure in the other system.
options.B: It only has one set of brake controls.
options.C: One system is called the "primary" system and the other one is called the "secondary" system.
options.D: All of the above are true.

en.description: A dual air brake system includes two independent systems, called the primary and secondary systems, and uses a single set of brake controls. All statements are correct.

en.question: Which of the following statements about spring brakes is correct?

options.A: Consisting of strong springs that are kept in place by air pressure when driving.
options.B: Until your air pressure drops to a particular range, often 20 to 30 psi, spring brakes will not exert its full effect.
options.C: Emergency brakes on a truck or tractor that activate when the air pressure gets too low.

en.description: Spring brakes serve as emergency brakes in heavy vehicles. They are held back by air pressure during driving, and fully activate if air pressure drops below about 20–30 psi. All statements are true.

en.question: If your ABS stops working, which of these is correct about your brakes?

options.A: Your brake lights will stop working.
options.B: Your brakes will only work at low speeds.
options.C: You will still be able to use your brakes but need to get the ABS fixed soon.
options.D: The ABS will work again if you pump your brake pedal

en.description: If ABS (Anti-lock Braking System) fails, your standard brakes will still function, but without the anti-lock feature. You should repair the ABS system soon.

en.question: Which of the following statements about slack adjusters is correct?

options.A: They are located between the push rod and S-Cam on drum brakes.
options.B: They are located between the power screw and push rod on disc brakes.
options.C: All of the above

en.description: Slack adjusters help maintain proper brake adjustment. Their location depends on the brake type: between the push rod and S-Cam for drum brakes, or between the power screw and push rod for disc brakes. All are correct.

en.question: What will happen if the low air pressure warning signal is not working correctly?

options.A: The vehicle's fuel efficiency will improve.
options.B: In a single-circuit air system, it could cause the brakes to stop quickly in an emergency
options.C: The vehicle's speed will increase due to reduced air resistance.

en.description: In a single-circuit air brake system, a malfunctioning low air pressure warning signal can prevent the driver from knowing when air pressure is dangerously low, potentially leading to sudden brake failure.

en.question: Why does the alcohol evaporator release the evaporated alcohol into the air system?

options.A: To make the brakes smell nice.
options.B: To cool down the engine.
options.C: To prevent ice buildup in the air brake system

en.description: The alcohol evaporator releases alcohol mist into the air brake system to prevent ice from forming in cold weather.

en.question: How can you make sure the air compressor governor is working correctly?

options.A: Listen for strange noises coming from the air compressor.
options.B: Raise the air pressure until the air compressor is turned off and then lower the air pressure; keep stepping on and off the brake pedal until the air compressor turns on.
options.C: Turn the engine on and off repeatedly to check if the air compressor responds.

en.description: To test the air compressor governor, build up air pressure until the compressor cuts out, then reduce the pressure by pressing the brake repeatedly until it cuts back in.

en.question: What's the most important thing to know about hard braking?

options.A: Increases fuel efficiency
options.B: Improves tire traction.
options.C: Don't lock the wheels for longer than a split second
options.D: Brake pads will wear out faster

en.description: When braking hard, avoid locking the wheels for more than a split second, as it can lead to loss of vehicle control.

en.question: Your truck got up to 40 mph going down a steep hill. You have to use your brakes to slow it down until it's going ___ mph.

options.A: 25 mph
options.B: 20 mph
options.C: 35 mph

en.description: When descending a steep hill, if your truck hits 40 mph, slow it down to 35 mph using your brakes.

en.question: When checking for air leaks in the air brake system, you should turn off the engine and hold the brake pedal down for one minute. The air pressure shouldn't go down by more than _ during that time.

options.A: 8 psi
options.B: 7 psi
options.C: 3 psi

en.description: During a leak check, with the engine off and brakes applied for one minute, air pressure loss should not exceed 3 psi.

en.question: How can you figure out how fast air is leaking when the truck is not moving?

options.A: Release the service brakes and observe the pressure gauge.
options.B: Turn off the engine, let go of the parking brake, and wait for the system to settle.
options.C: Engage the service brakes and monitor fuel levels.

en.description: To check the rate of air leakage, turn off the engine, release the parking brake, and let the system settle before observing the pressure.

en.question: When should you use both the parking brakes and the air brakes at the same time?

options.A: When the vehicle is being loaded or unloaded.
options.B: Before starting your driving shift.
options.C: Never do that
options.D: Any time you need to stop quickly

en.description: You should never use parking brakes and air (service) brakes at the same time, as it can damage the system.

en.question: How should you correctly use anti-lock brakes?

options.A: Brake normally
options.B: Slam the brakes continuously.
options.C: Pump the brakes rapidly.

en.description: With ABS, just brake normally. The system will manage wheel lock-up.

en.question: How do you properly set a manual slack adjuster?

options.A: Pull the release lever while turning the adjusting nut clockwise.
options.B: Screw the adjusting nut until the slack adjuster's end stops moving toward the air chamber. Then turn the nut a quarter of a turn in the other direction to pull the brake shoes away from the inside of the brake drum.
options.C: Tighten the adjusting nut with a hammer until it feels tight.

en.description: To adjust a manual slack adjuster, turn the nut until contact, then back off a quarter turn to ensure clearance.

en.question: Where can you find the foundation brakes?

options.A: All the wheels.
options.B: On the roof of the vehicle
options.C: Under the driver's seat

en.description: Foundation brakes are installed on all the wheels and are the main braking components of the vehicle.

en.question: Which vehicles must be equipped with a low air pressure warning system?

options.A: After the year 2000, new vehicles must feature low-air-pressure warnings.
options.B: Vehicles with manual brakes only.
options.C: All air brake-equipped vehicles must have low-pressure warning lights to drive on the roads.

en.description: Any vehicle that uses air brakes must have a warning signal for low air pressure to be allowed on the road.

en.question: If you're driving a truck-trailer combination vehicle equipped with ABS, which one of these things is NOT something you do when braking?

options.A: Only use as much brake as you need to stay in control safely.
options.B: When slowing down, watch your tractor and trailer and ease off the brakes.
options.C: Brake normally regardless of the ABS brakes
options.D: Step on the gas pedal to speed up which would keep the trailer and truck straight.

en.description: You should not accelerate to try and keep the truck and trailer straight; this is unsafe.

en.question: For the S-cam drum brakes to work, they need air to be pushed into each brake chamber first. The force of the air pressure pushes the pushrod outward. The rod then moves ___ which makes ___ rotate.

options.A: Pushrod; steering wheel
options.B: Kingpin; fifth wheel
options.C: Slack adjuster; brake camshaft

en.description: The pushrod moves the slack adjuster, which turns the brake camshaft and activates the brakes.

en.question: Before going down a hill, you must change to the right gear __

options.A: So you just need to use the brake enough to feel a slowdown.
options.B: To allow you to cruise downward.
options.C: So that you may shift through the gears on the downhill.

en.description: Before descending, choose the proper gear so that only light braking is needed to control your speed.

en.question: What should you do before you leave a vehicle unattended?

options.A: Take starter key with you.
options.B: Engage the parking brakes.
options.C: Place the wheel chocks.

en.description: Before leaving a vehicle unattended, you should take the key, set the parking brake, and block the wheels.

en.question: How can you check if the truck's slack adjusters are functioning correctly?

options.A: Park on level area, turn off the parking brakes, and pull each slack adjuster hard. Check to see if it moves less than 1 inch.
options.B: Park on level area, put on the parking brakes and keep pressing the brake pedal.
options.C: Park on level area, release the parking, press the gas pedal, and see if the adjuster moves or not.

en.description: To test slack adjusters, pull on each one with the brakes released. If it moves more than 1 inch, it needs adjustment.

en.question: Why should you drain air tanks?

options.A: They may overheat
options.B: Your brakes could emit a loud noise.
options.C: To ensure the headlights always stay on.
options.D: The frozen water may cause the brakes to fail.

en.description: Draining the air tanks removes moisture that can freeze and prevent the brakes from working properly.

en.question: What does the handbrake control?

options.A: The brakes when you are driving in reverse.
options.B: The brakes when you are changing lanes.
options.C: It releases the air out of the brake chambers.

en.description: The handbrake releases air from the brake chambers, engaging the spring brakes to hold the vehicle in place.

en.question: How do brakes work when going down a long, steep hill?

options.A: By increasing the vehicle's speed to reduce strain.
options.B: As a supplement and the engine braking effect as the main.
options.C: By using only the vehicle's weight to slow down.

en.description: Engine braking should be the primary method of speed control on long descents, with brakes used only to assist.

en.question: Can you use the spring brakes and air brakes at the same time?

options.A: Yes, only when carrying heavy loads.
options.B: Yes, but only at high speeds.
options.C: No, never.

en.description: Spring brakes are for parking or emergencies, not for use while driving. Never use both at once.

en.question: Why do we use an alcohol evaporator?

options.A: To clean the air filters more efficiently.
options.B: To increase fuel efficiency by adding alcohol to the engine.
options.C: Reduce the risk of icing in air brake valves in cold weather.

en.description: An alcohol evaporator helps prevent ice from forming in the air brake valves when it's cold, ensuring the brakes work properly.

en.question: If your truck has an alcohol evaporator, what should you do with it when the weather gets cold?

options.A: Drain and remove the evaporator.
options.B: Check and fill the alcohol level.
options.C: Adjust the coolant system for alcohol.

en.description: In cold weather, ensure the evaporator has enough alcohol to prevent freezing in the air brake system.

en.question: What brake system applies and releases the brakes when the driver steps on the brake pedal?

options.A: Automatic
options.B: Service
options.C: Manual

en.description: The service brake system is used for normal braking when the brake pedal is pressed.

en.question: If your vehicle doesn't have automatic tank drains, you should drain the oil and water from the bottom of the air tanks _

options.A: Every month.
options.B: Before starting the engine each morning.
options.C: At the end of each day of driving.

en.description: Daily draining prevents moisture buildup that can cause brake system issues.

en.question: How do you normally engage the parking brakes?

options.A: Shift into neutral gear.
options.B: Push the gas pedal down.
options.C: Apply brakes by pulling the parking brake control knob out.

en.description: Pulling out the control knob engages the spring brakes, securing the vehicle when parked.

en.question: The safety valve lowers pressure when it reaches __ psi.
en.description: The safety valve opens at 150 psi to release excess pressure and protect the system.

en.question: A low air pressure warning signal must appear when the air pressure in the tank falls below__ psi.
en.description: A warning light activates at 60 psi to alert the driver of dangerously low air pressure. In some states, it's 55 psi.

en.question: What does the air compressor governor control?

options.A: The amount of fuel the engine uses
options.B: The temperature of the engine.
options.C: When air is pumped into the air tanks.

en.description: The governor tells the air compressor when to start and stop filling the air tanks.

en.question: When you use the service brakes too much, they can get too hot and this can cause _.

options.A: Expansion of the brake drums.
options.B: Decreased fuel efficiency
options.C: Reduced tire pressure

en.description: Overuse of brakes causes drum expansion from heat, reducing braking effectiveness.

en.question: If the air pressure doesn't go up to the needed level fast enough, then:

options.A: The headlights could become dimmer.
options.B: You might need to adjust the mirrors more frequently.
options.C: Air pressure may drop to a low point while driving, requiring an emergency stop.

en.description: If air pressure builds too slowly, it may drop dangerously low during driving, requiring an emergency stop.

en.question: Which of the following types of foundation brakes are most commonly found on heavy vehicles?

options.A: Air pad
options.B: S-cam drum.
options.C: Hydraulic disc

en.description: The S-cam drum brake is widely used on heavy vehicles like trucks and buses due to its durability and effectiveness.

en.question: What statement about spring brake braking power is correct?

options.A: It depends on the service brakes being in adjustment.
options.B: It decreases as the vehicle's speed increases.
options.C: It is most effective when the vehicle is fully loaded.

en.description: Spring brakes rely on the service brakes being properly adjusted in order to apply sufficient stopping force.

en.question: Air brakes have a longer total stopping distance than hydraulic brakes due to ___ distance.

options.A: Acceleration distance
options.B: Brake lag
options.C: Cooling time

en.description: Brake lag refers to the delay between pressing the pedal and the brakes activating in air brake systems, increasing stopping distance.

en.question: If you pull hard on a slack adjuster and it moves more than __, it needs to be adjusted.

options.A: 5/8 inch
options.B: 1 inch
options.C: 3 inches

en.description: Slack adjusters should not move more than 1 inch when pulled. If they do, the brakes are out of adjustment.

en.question: At what psi does the air compressor stop pumping air?
en.description: The compressor stops at 125 psi to maintain optimal pressure and prevent overloading the system.

en.question: What happens if your vehicle's brake drums overheat?

options.A: They expand.
options.B: They crack and leak fluid.
options.C: They glow bright red

en.description: Overheated brake drums expand, reducing braking effectiveness due to increased clearance with the brake shoes.

en.question: Excessive heat caused by overusing your brakes can also cause _.

options.A: Engine oil to overheat.
options.B: Tire pressure to decrease.
options.C: Brake to fade or fail.

en.description: Too much heat can lead to brake fade or failure, making it harder or impossible to stop the vehicle safely.

en.question: What is the purpose of a brake light switch?

options.A: It activates the turn signals when you apply the brakes
options.B: It turns on the brake lights when you put on the air brakes.
options.C: It adjusts the brightness of your headlights.

en.description: The brake light switch activates the rear brake lights when the brake pedal is pressed, alerting other drivers.

en.question: When going down a steep hill and reaching your safe speed of 40 mph, you would use the brake until your speed goes down to __mph.
en.description: To prevent overheating, brake until your speed is reduced to 35 mph, then release the brakes to let them cool.

en.question: When the air pressure falls below___ psi, the straight truck spring brakes will come fully on.
en.description: When driving a straight truck, if the air pressure gets too low, special brakes called spring brakes kick in to stop you. This happens when the air pressure drops below 20 psi (pounds per square inch). It's a safety feature to prevent accidents when there's not enough air pressure for the regular brakes..

en.question: What does the term "Wig Wag" mean?

options.A: A light that flashes when the engine is overheating
options.B: A mechanical arm that signals low air pressure
options.C: A lever that controls the speed of the engine.

en.description: A 'Wig Wag' is a mechanical arm that drops down as a visual warning when air pressure in the brake system is dangerously low.

en.question: Why is it important to remove water from the compressed air tanks?

options.A: Water is removed because its presence might cause the tank to change color, which is thought to be a sign of wear.
options.B: Water is removed from the compressed air tanks to make the system lighter and improve fuel efficiency.
options.C: Water can freeze in cold weather and cause brake failure.

en.description: Water in air tanks can freeze in cold weather, blocking air flow and leading to brake failure.

en.question: Parking or emergency brakes must be kept in position by something that does not leak, like:

options.A: Spring pressure.
options.B: Magnetic force
options.C: Electric current

en.description: Spring pressure holds the parking or emergency brakes in place without relying on air or electricity, which can leak or fail.

en.question: Your truck is equipped with a dual air brake system and minimum-size air tanks. How long should it take for the air pressure to go up from 85 to 100 psi?
en.description: The air pressure should rise from 85 to 100 psi in 45 seconds or less in a properly functioning dual air brake system.

en.question: How can you tell if your brakes are fading?

options.A: Less pressure is needed on the brake pedal for each stop.
options.B: You have to push harder on a brake pedal to control your speed on a downgrade.
options.C: The vehicle stops more quickly than usual.

en.description: Brake fade means the brakes are losing effectiveness, and you'll need to push harder to slow the vehicle, especially on hills.

en.question: You should NOT apply the parking brake, _

options.A: If it's raining lightly outside.
options.B: If the brakes are very hot (e.g. Just after coming down a steep grade).
options.C: If the parking area is completely flat and secure.

en.description: Applying the parking brake when the brakes are hot can damage the system or cause it to lock up.

en.question: The safety valve automatically open at__

options.A: 200 psi
options.B: 75 psi
options.C: 150 psi

en.description: The safety valve opens at 150 psi to release excess air and protect the system from overpressure damage.

en.question: When the spring brakes are activated, when is it okay to press the brake pedal?

options.A: Only at a full stop.
options.B: Only when making sharp turns.
options.C: Never.

en.description: Pressing the brake pedal when spring brakes are on can damage the braking system. You should never do this.

en.question: What holds the air in the tanks if there is a leak in the air compressor?

options.A: The dual circuit brake system
options.B: The one-way check valve.
options.C: The pressure release valve

en.description: The one-way check valve allows air into the tank but prevents it from flowing back out, maintaining pressure even if the compressor fails.

en.question: Using your brakes too much can also cause:

options.A: Brake to fade or fail.
options.B: Tire pressure to decrease.
options.C: Brake fluid to evaporate.

en.description: Excessive brake use generates heat, which can lead to brake fade or complete failure.

en.question: When is it safe to leave your truck unattended without applying parking brakes and chocking the wheels?

options.A: If you are parked on a flat surface.
options.B: Never.
options.C: If you are only away for a few minutes.

en.description: It is never safe to leave your truck without applying the parking brakes and chocking the wheels, regardless of the situation.

en.question: What pressure (PSI) in the service air tank triggers the low air pressure warning?
en.description: The low air pressure warning comes on when the pressure drops to 60 psi, alerting the driver to a potentially dangerous condition.

en.question: To check if the air service brakes function properly, you should:

options.A: Brake gently while the vehicle is in neutral.
options.B: Press the brake pedal repeatedly while the vehicle is stationary.
options.C: Brake firmly while slowly moving forward.

en.description: To check brake function, move forward slowly and apply the brakes firmly to ensure they engage correctly.

en.question: How can you check that your service brakes are functioning properly?

options.A: Drive at a high speed, then slam on the brakes to see if the vehicle stops quickly.
options.B: Park on a slight slope, drain off air pressure, set the parking brake and check movement.
options.C: Park on level ground, wait until normal air pressure is reached, release the parking brake and move forward slowly at about 5 mph. Then apply the brakes firmly.

en.description: This is the safest and proper method to test service brake function without risking vehicle damage or loss of control.

en.question: In vehicles with dual parking control valves, you can use pressure from a separate tank to _.

options.A: Release the spring emergency/parking brakes to move a short distance.
options.B: Check the tire pressure without exiting the vehicle.
options.C: Fill the fuel tank without going to a gas station.

en.description: The auxiliary air tank allows for temporary release of the spring brakes to move the vehicle a short distance in emergencies.

en.question: To go down a steep, long grade, select the right gear first. Then, to brake correctly, slow down until you're going about __ miles per hour slower than the speed limit, and then release the brakes.

options.A: 25 mph
options.B: 5 mph
options.C: 20 mph

en.description: Brake until your speed drops 5 mph below your safe speed, then release the brakes to avoid overheating them.

en.question: A truck or bus emergency or parking brakes can be legally held by a/an__ pressure.

options.A: Hydraulic
options.B: Magnetic
options.C: Spring

en.description: Spring pressure is the standard legal method to hold parking or emergency brakes in trucks and buses.

en.question: Spring brakes are usually held back by — during normal driving.

options.A: Air pressure.
options.B: Hydraulic fluid
options.C: Magnetic force

en.description: Under normal conditions, air pressure keeps the spring brakes released. If air pressure drops, the springs engage the brakes.

en.question: What is the purpose of the S-cam?

options.A: Rotates the wheels at different speeds for better handling.
options.B: Adjusts the tire pressure for optimal braking.
options.C: Forces the brake shoes against the inside of the brake drum.

en.description: The S-cam mechanism applies the brake shoes against the drum to create friction and stop the vehicle.

en.question: The braking power of the spring brakes:

options.A: Decreases as the speed of the vehicle increases.
options.B: Depends on the brakes being in adjustment.
options.C: Increases when the vehicle is fully loaded.

en.description: The effectiveness of spring brakes relies on proper adjustment of the braking system. Poor adjustment can lead to brake failure.

en.question: When driving down a long and steep hill, using the brakes should only be an extra help to:

options.A: Use of spring brakes.
options.B: The use of the front brakes limiting valve.
options.C: The braking effect of the engine.

en.description: On steep downgrades, the engine's braking power should be the main method of control, with brakes used only as needed to assist.

en.question: If you have to stop quickly in an emergency, make sure you brake in a way that:

options.A: Will allow you to steer and keep your vehicle in a straight line.
options.B: Will allow you to turn sharply to avoid obstacles.
options.C: Will make your vehicle spin to reduce speed.

en.description: Maintaining steering control and a straight path is key to avoiding accidents during emergency braking.

en.question: All vehicles with air brakes have:

options.A: An automatic pressure adjustment system.
options.B: A supply pressure gauge.
options.C: A manual air control valve.

en.description: Every air brake-equipped vehicle includes a gauge that shows the air supply pressure to monitor brake system readiness.

en.question: How many feet does a truck or bus with air brakes need to stop if going 55 mph under perfect conditions?

options.A: Exactly 150 feet.
options.B: Exactly 250 feet.
options.C: More than 300 feet.

en.description: At 55 mph, a vehicle with air brakes can take about 450 feet to stop—so the correct answer is more than 300 feet.

en.question: If you keep pushing and letting go of the pedal over and over, it could cause__

options.A: A loss of brake air pressure.
options.B: A buildup of brake air pressure.
options.C: Increased fuel consumption.

en.description: Repeatedly pressing and releasing the brake pedal can quickly reduce air pressure, leading to brake failure.

en.question: What should you do first and right away when the low air pressure alarm goes off?

options.A: Stop and safely park as soon as possible.
options.B: Check the oil level.
options.C: Continue driving and monitor the situation.

en.description: A low air pressure warning indicates a potential brake failure. Stop and park the vehicle safely immediately.

en.question: What is the purpose of draining compressed air tanks of water?

options.A: Water can freeze in cold weather and cause brake failure.
options.B: Water low boiling point reduces braking power.
options.C: To prevent air leaks in the tires.

en.description: Water in the air tanks can freeze and block airflow, potentially causing brakes to fail in cold weather.

en.question: When should you use the parking brake on a vehicle with air brakes?

options.A: Any time when vehicle is parked.
options.B: Only during vehicle inspection.
options.C: When making a quick stop.

en.description: Always apply the parking brake when parking to secure the vehicle and prevent it from rolling.

en.question: If you need to stop quickly because of an emergency, you should brake in a manner that lets you__

options.A: Switch to neutral and let the vehicle coast.
options.B: Tap the gas pedal lightly before braking.
options.C: Keep your vehicle in a straight line.

en.description: Braking in a straight line during emergencies helps maintain control and avoid skidding.

en.question: How should you check the free play of S-cam brakes' manual slack adjusters?

options.A: Park on a slope, engage the parking brake, and check with the engine running.
options.B: Park on level ground, chock the wheels and release the parking brakes.
options.C: Park on a slope and check without chocking the wheels.

en.description: To safely check slack adjusters, park on flat ground, chock the wheels to prevent movement, and release the parking brakes.

en.question: If your truck or bus has a dual-air brake system and one of them shows a low air pressure warning, what should you do?

options.A: Increase your speed to reach your destination quicker.
options.B: Check your mirrors for traffic before deciding to continue driving.
options.C: Stop right away and safely park. Continue only after the system is fixed.

en.description: If your truck or bus with two air brake systems shows a low air warning for one system, don't keep driving. Stop safely as soon as you can and fix the problem before you go any further.

en.question: Why do brakes that use air take longer to work than those that use liquid?

options.A: Air brakes have larger pistons.
options.B: Air brakes take more time to flow through the lines than hydraulic fluid.
options.C: Air brakes need to warm up before use.

en.description: Air brakes take longer to start working than liquid-based brakes because air moves slower through the brake lines than liquid does.

en.question: The application pressure gauge shows how much air pressure you _.

options.A: Are applying to the brakes.
options.B: Need to refill the air compressor.
options.C: Have in the hydraulic fluid system

en.description: The application pressure gauge shows how much pressure you're using when you press the brakes.

en.question: The safety valve will automatically let go of extra pressure when the pressure hits _ psi.
en.description: If the pressure gets too high, at 150 psi, the safety valve will open to release excess pressure.

en.question: The supply pressure gauge tells you___

options.A: How much pressure is in the air tanks.
options.B: The temperature of the air compressor
options.C: The speed of the vehicle

en.description: The supply pressure gauge tells you how much air pressure is in the tanks.

en.question: What can legally keep the parking or emergency brakes on trucks, truck-trailers, or buses in place?

options.A: Magnetic force
options.B: Spring pressure.
options.C: Gravity

en.description: The parking or emergency brakes on large vehicles use spring pressure to stay applied and work correctly.

en.question: When you use the brakes, the brake shoes will push against the:

options.A: Brake drum or disc.
options.B: Wheel axle
options.C: Tire rim

en.description: When you press the brakes, the brake shoes push against the brake drum or disc to stop the vehicle.

en.question: When the straight truck engine is off and the brakes are on, the air loss rate should not exceed__

options.A: 3 psi in one minute.
options.B: 4 psi in 2 minutes
options.C: 5 psi in 3 minutes

en.description: With the engine off and brakes applied, air loss should not exceed 3 psi in one minute to ensure safe braking.

en.question: The parking brake on a vehicle with air brakes should be used:

options.A: To stop at traffic lights.
options.B: Whenever you leave the vehicle unattended.
options.C: When you're driving at a high speed.

en.description: Always use the parking brake when leaving the vehicle to prevent it from moving.

en.question: At what psi is an air brake system considered to be fully charged?
en.description: An air brake system is considered fully charged at 125 psi, meaning it's at full operating capacity.

en.question: The brake pedal in an air brake system:

options.A: Controls the air pressure applied to the brakes.
options.B: Adjusts the temperature of the brake pads.
options.C: Increases the amount of fuel to the engine

en.description: The brake pedal in an air brake system controls how much air pressure goes to the brakes.

en.question: Some trucks have an alcohol evaporator. What may happen if you don't maintain the right level of alcohol in it?

options.A: The brakes may overheat and stop working properly.
options.B: Ice may form in the air brake valves and cause brake failure.
options.C: The brake fluid could evaporate, leading to total brake loss.

en.description: If the alcohol level in the air brake system is too low, ice can build up in the valves, leading to brake failure.

en.question: If your truck has a dual air brake system and one of them doesn't have enough pressure:

options.A: The system will automatically redistribute the available pressure, ensuring that all brakes remain fully effective.
options.B: The brake pedal will feel unusually soft.
options.C: Either the front or rear brakes will not be fully functional.

en.description: If one part of a dual air brake system fails, either the front or back brakes might not work properly.

en.question: When the engine is turned off and the brakes are not applied, the air brake system in a straight truck or bus shouldn't lose more than __ psi every minute.
en.description: The system should not lose more than 2 psi per minute when the engine is off and brakes are not applied.

en.question: When driving at 55 mph on a dry road, how many feet will air brake lag distance add to your total stopping distance?
en.description: At 55 mph on a dry road, air brake lag adds 32 feet to the total stopping distance.

en.question: What will happen if your truck has a dual air system and one loses air pressure?

options.A: The brake lights will remain on continuously.
options.B: The truck will automatically speed up.
options.C: Either the front or back brake will not be fully operational.

en.description: If one part of the dual air system fails, either the front or rear brakes will not function properly.

en.question: How do you do emergency stab braking the right way?

options.A: Pump the brakes gently until the vehicle stops.
options.B: Apply your brakes all the way. Release the brakes when wheels lock up. As soon as the wheels start rolling, apply the brakes fully again.
options.C: Turn off the engine immediately.

en.description: Emergency stab braking: brake hard, release if wheels lock, then reapply when wheels start rolling.

en.question: What tells you how much air pressure is in the tanks?

options.A: Fuel meter
options.B: Water level indicator
options.C: Supply pressure gauge

en.description: The supply pressure gauge shows how much air pressure is in the tanks.

en.question: What should you do if your truck or bus has dual air brakes and a warning light turns on because one system has low pressure?

options.A: Ignore the warning and focus on your driving.
options.B: Bring your vehicle to a complete stop right B away and safely park. Continue only after the system is fixed.
options.C: Continue driving as normal and check the system after your trip.

en.description: Stop the vehicle safely and park it. Fix the system before driving again if the low-pressure warning light comes on.

en.question: It's not safe to drive a vehicle if its brake drums have cracks bigger than of the friction area.
en.description: If brake drums have cracks wider than half the friction area, the vehicle is unsafe to drive.

en.question: Air brakes consist of three different braking systems: service, parking and _.

options.A: Emergency
options.B: Hydraulic
options.C: Disc

en.description: The emergency brake is a backup system that works if the main brakes fail, using parts of the service and parking brakes.

en.question: How many extra feet does it take for an air brake to start working when you're going 55 mph on a dry road?
en.description: At 55 mph on a dry road, air brake lag adds 32 feet to the time it takes for the brakes to start slowing the truck down.

en.question: Whenever you park, always use the parking brakes, except:

options.A: If the brakes are very hot (e.g., after just coming down a steep grade).
options.B: If the parking area is completely level.
options.C: If the parking spot is designated for short-term parking only.

en.description: Do not use the parking brakes if they are too hot from heavy braking after descending a steep hill.

en.question: When testing combination vehicles with the engine off and brakes applied, the air pressure should not drop more than _ psi every minute.
en.description: For combination vehicles, air pressure should not fall more than 4 psi per minute when the engine is off and brakes are applied.

en.question: When is it NOT a good time to use the parking brakes?

options.A: To brake vehicle very hard, in other word when coming down the steep grade.

options.C: In an emergency brake failure

en.question: Emergency controlled braking is when you

options.A: Apply the brakes as hard as you can without locking the wheels.
options.B: Press down on the accelerator while lightly tapping the brakes.
options.C: Turn off the engine and coast to a stop.

en.question: The service line has a big leak, so you hit the brakes. Service air pressure will escape, causing -

options.A: Engine to overheat
options.B: Brakes to release automatically.
options.C: Trailer emergency brakes to come on.

en.question: Before you drive a truck or bus that has a dual air brake system, the air pressure needs to be at least _ psi.

en.question: What does the brake pedal do in an air brake system?

options.A: Sends signals to the vehicle's lights and indicators.
options.B: Controls the air pressure applied to put on the brakes.
options.C: Adjusts the vehicle's steering direction.

en.question: What is true about the antilock braking system?

options.A: ABS makes your tires last longer.
options.B: ABS changes the way you brake in emergencies.
options.C: ABS improves fuel efficiency.

en.description: ABS prevents wheels from locking during braking, helping maintain steering control.

en.question: The modulating control valve lets you control:

options.A: Spring brakes.
options.B: Rear wheel speed
options.C: Tire pressure balance

en.question: Can you use the spring brakes and air brakes at the same time?

options.A: Yes, only when carrying heavy loads.
options.B: Yes, but only at high speeds.
options.C: No, never.

en.description: No, spring brakes and air brakes can't be used at the same time. Spring brakes are for parking or emergencies, and air brakes are used while driving. Using both at once could cause problems.

en.question: Which part does NOT belong to a drum brake?

options.A: Return spring
options.B: Safety valve
options.C: Slack adjuster

en.question: Which part does NOT belong to a drum brake?

options.A: Return spring
options.B: Safety valve
options.C: Slack adjuster

en.description: The correct answer is: Safety valve. Drum brakes are parts in some vehicles that help stop the car, but a safety valve isn't part of them.

en.question: What might go wrong with the brakes if there is oil and water in the air tanks?

options.A: The brakes could heat up more than usual.
options.B: The brakes might not work.
options.C: The brakes might make strange noises.

en.description: If oil and water get into the air tanks of a truck, the brakes might not work properly. This is because the oil and water can mess up how the brake system works.

en.question: At what air pressure should the air compressor start working?

en.question: If the vehicle has air brakes and a trailer, you must check the air connections between the truck and the trailer as part of the vehicle inspection test. You must ensure the - are securely fastened and free from damage or air leaks.

options.A: Glad hands
options.B: Hoses
options.C: Tires

en.description: For a truck with air brakes and a trailer, when you check the truck, make sure the 'glad hands' — the parts connecting the trailer's brakes to the truck — are tightly attached and not broken or leaking air.

en.question: If the air compressor fails to perform properly, -

options.A: There will still be enough air in the tanks to use the air brakes a few times.
options.B: The vehicle can continue to be driven as normal without any issues.
options.C: You will no longer have air to use and will only have spring brake or emergency brake use.

en.description: If the air compressor doesn't work right, you'll still have some air left in the tanks to use the air brakes a few times.

en.question: What's the right way to check if your truck's emergency brakes turn on automatically?

options.A: Keep pressing on and off the brake pedal until pressure is below the manufacturer's specification for the spring brakes to activate
options.B: Keep pressing on and off the brake pedal on single vehicles until the parking brake valve comes out.
options.C: All of the above

en.description: All answers are correct. These methods help check if the emergency (spring) brakes activate automatically when air pressure gets too low.

en.question: What should you do when you have to stop quickly in an emergency using the 'stab braking' technique?

options.A: Turn off the engine immediately.
options.B: Gradually slow down by shifting into a lower gear.
options.C: Press hard on the brake pedal, release the brakes when the wheels lock, then reapply the brakes when the wheels begin to roll.

en.description: When you need to stop quickly using 'stab braking,' push the brake hard until the wheels stop turning, then let go of the brake until the wheels start moving again, and push the brake hard once more.

en.question: A converter dolly that has anti-lock brakes must have _

options.A: One red lamp on the front.
options.B: Two yellow lamps on the back.
options.C: One yellow lamp on the left side.

en.question: You need __ to drive a truck-trailer equipped with air brakes.

options.A: A Class D CDL
options.B: A Class A CDL without an air brakes restriction.
options.C: A Class B CDL without an air brakes restriction.

en.description: To drive a big truck with air brakes, you need a special driver's license called a Class A CDL, and it can't say you're not allowed to use air brakes.

en.question: If you're driving a vehicle that has a front brake limiting valve, you should

options.A: Only use it in heavy traffic conditions.
options.B: Always set it to normal mode
options.C: Switch it off during rain.

en.description: If your truck has a special control that changes how the front brakes work, you should always keep this control in the normal setting. Keeping it normal helps make sure your truck stops the right way and keeps you safe on the road.

en.question: Air brakes work by using ___ to operate the brakes.

options.A: Hydraulic fluid
options.B: Carbon dioxide
options.C: Pressurized air

en.description: Air brakes in big trucks work with pressurized air. This means they use air that's pushed together tightly to make the brakes stop the truck.

en.question: Which of the following statements about slack adjusters is correct?

options.A: They are located between the push rod and S-Cam on drum brakes.
options.B: They are located between the power screw and push rod on disc brakes.
options.C: All of the above

en.question: Before going down a hill, you must change to the right gear _

options.A: So you just need to use the brake enough to feel a slowdown.
options.B: To allow you to cruise downward.
options.C: So that you may shift through the gears on the downhill.

en.description: Before you go down a hill, you should change to the right gear so you only have to lightly use your brakes to slow down a bit.

en.question: How can you tell if your brakes are fading?

options.A: Less pressure is needed on the brake pedal for each stop.
options.B: You have to push harder on a brake pedal to control your speed on a downgrade.
options.C: The vehicle stops more quickly than usual.

en.description: When your brakes are wearing out, it takes longer to stop your truck. You also have to press the brake pedal harder than before to slow down, especially when going downhill.

en.question: If you need to stop quickly because of an emergency, you should brake in a manner that lets you___

options.A: Switch to neutral and let the vehicle coast.
options.B: Tap the gas pedal lightly before braking
options.C: Keep your vehicle in a straight line.

en.description: When you need to stop fast in an emergency, make sure you brake in a way that keeps your vehicle moving straight ahead. This helps you stay in control and avoid skidding or spinning out.

en.question: Air brakes consist of three different braking systems: service, parking and -

options.A: Emergency
options.B: Hydraulic
options.C: Disc

en.question: Why do you have to demonstrate your knowledge by passing the exam on air brakes?

options.A: If not, you will have to get a restricted CDL.
options.B: To ensure your vehicle doesn't use too much fuel.
options.C: To make sure you can drive safely in the rain.

en.question: How do baffles in baffled tanks contribute to managing liquid movement?

options.A: Controlling both forward and backward liquid surges
options.B: Reducing the speed of the truck
options.C: Increasing fuel efficiency

en.description: Baffles in tanks help stop the liquid from sloshing too much forward and backward. This makes it easier to control the truck when it's moving.

en.question: Which statement best characterizes baffled tanks?

options.A: Baffled tanks have double walls for extra insulation.
options.B: Baffled tanks have bulkheads with openings that let liquid flow through to other smaller tanks inside the tank shell.
options.C: Baffled tanks are equipped with external vents to reduce internal pressure.

en.question: You should inspect the intake, discharge, and cut-off valves before driving, loading, or unloading the vehicle __

options.A: To confirm the valves are properly labeled.
options.B: To ensure they are in the correct position
options.C: To verify the color of the valves.

en.description: Before driving, loading, or unloading your vehicle, you should check the intake, discharge, and cut-off valves to make sure they are in the right position.

en.question: Before loading, unloading, or driving a tanker, what precautionary steps should you take?

options.A: Make sure your cargo is covered with a tarp.
options.B: Check the weather forecast.
options.C: Inspect the vehicle.

en.description: Before you do anything with a tanker, like loading, unloading, or driving it, you need to carefully check the vehicle to make sure everything is in good condition and safe to use.

en.question: When inspecting tankers, what is the primary concern to assess?

options.A: Leaks
options.B: Tire pressure
options.C: Brake lights functionality

en.description: When checking tankers, the top priority is to look for leaks. This is crucial because leaks can lead to serious accidents or environmental harm.

en.question: A tank must have extra space for the liquid to expand when it gets warmer. What is this called?

options.A: Outage
options.B: Distillation
options.C: Decomposition

en.description: When liquids get warm, they take up more space. So, tanks need extra room for this bigger amount of liquid. This extra space is called 'Outage.'

en.question: What alternative term refers to tanks without baffles?

options.A: Smooth bore tanks
options.B: Bulk liquid containers
options.C: Non-pressurized vessels

en.description: Unbaffled tanks are also called smooth bore tanks. These tanks don't have dividers inside to slow down liquid movement, making the vehicle harder to control.

en.question: When filling up and emptying a smaller tank formed by a bulkhead division, where should you avoid placing weight?

options.A: The front tank
options.B: The rear tank
options.C: Both the front and rear tanks

en.description: When filling or emptying a smaller section in a big tank that's divided up, don't put heavy stuff in both the front and back sections. This helps keep the tank stable.

en.question: Which of these safety tips should you not follow when driving a tanker truck?

options.A: Brake gently through curves.
options.B: Accelerate gently through curves.
options.C: Use stab braking for quick stops.

en.description: Braking gently through curves is unsafe for tanker trucks because the liquid cargo can shift and destabilize the truck. Slow down before entering the curve instead.

en.question: When navigating turns or curved roads with a partially filled baffled tanker, what should you do to ensure safety?

options.A: Drive slowly and carefully.
options.B: Brake sharply before every turn.
options.C: Accelerate quickly after the turn.

en.description: When driving a partially filled baffled tanker, it's important to go slowly and be very careful around turns or on curved roads to keep the liquid inside stable and prevent accidents.

en.question: What do people call the smaller sections inside some liquid tankers?

options.A: Fluid partitions
options.B: Liquid compartments
options.C: Bulkheads

en.description: In some big trucks that carry liquids, there are smaller sections inside the tank to keep the liquid in place. These are called bulkheads. They help make sure the liquid doesn't move too much, which can make driving safer.

en.question: Which section of the tank should you inspect for dents or leaks?

options.A: The body or shell of the tank
options.B: Tire pressure indicators
options.C: Fuel gauge

en.description: Check the tank's main part for any dents or leaks. This doesn't include checking the tires or how much fuel you have.

en.question: What are unbaffled tanks?

options.A: They are liquid tanks that do not contain any separating devices to stop the flow of liquid.
options.B: They are liquid tanks that have a high risk of forward to backward liquid surge.
options.C: Both

en.description: Unbaffled tanks are special containers without internal barriers. This means when the truck moves or stops, the liquid inside can slosh around freely. This sloshing can make driving tricky because it affects how the truck moves.

en.question: What precaution should you take when maneuvering curves with liquid tanks on highways or on/off ramps?

options.A: Make quick and sharp turns.
options.B: Keep the steering wheel straight at all times.
options.C: Drive well below the posted speed limit.

en.description: Slow down more than the speed signs say when you drive on curved roads or ramps. This helps keep you safe because the liquid in tanks moves a lot and can make controlling the truck harder.

en.question: What triggers the movement of liquid inside tanks, resulting in a surge?

options.A: It is caused by a crack in the tank.
options.B: It is caused by the movement in partially filled liquid tanks.
options.C: It happens when the temperature of the liquid changes.

en.description: When a tank is only partially filled with liquid, the liquid can move around easily inside. This movement causes a surge or a sudden increase in the motion of the liquid, which can lead to splashing or even instability of the tank.

en.question: What type of cargo is typically carried by unbaffled tankers?

options.A: Flammable liquids such as gasoline or diesel fuels.
options.B: Food products such as milk
options.C: Dry goods like flour

en.description: Food products like milk are usually transported in unbaffled tankers because the smooth, undivided interior makes cleaning and sanitizing easier. This design helps prevent contamination and preserves the purity of sensitive cargo.

en.question: What does "high center of gravity" mean?

options.A: It means that the height of your tanker is 5 meters high off the ground.
options.B: It means that most of the load weight of the tanker is carried high above and off the road.
options.C: It means that your seat in the vehicle is higher than the tank body so you're in the center of gravity.

en.description: It means that most of the weight of what your truck is carrying is up high, far above the ground. This can make the truck more likely to tip over if not driven carefully.

en.question: When inspecting the manhole covers and vents, what is your primary task?

options.A: Replace the covers with plastic ones for lighter weight.
options.B: Paint the covers for better visibility
options.C: Check to see if the covers have gaskets that close properly and see if the vents are clear.

en.description: Check if the covers seal right and if nothing's blocking the vents.

en.question: What is the primary reason for filling a tank only partially?

options.A: The liquid cargo is temperature-sensitive.
options.B: The liquid cargo is non-flammable.
options.C: The liquid cargo has high density.

en.description: High-density liquids add significant weight, so filling the tank completely could exceed safe limits. By only partially filling the tank, you maintain a manageable total weight and reduce the risk of damage or instability.

en.question: How much liquid you can put in a tank depends on what?

options.A: The weight of the liquid
options.B: The weight limits of the tanker
options.C: Both

en.description: The amount of liquid you can put in a tank depends on two things. First, it depends on the weight of the liquid itself. Second, it depends on how much weight the tank can hold without getting damaged or breaking.

en.question: When filling up a tanker with 3 or 4 valves at its bottom, how should you position the valves?

options.A: Locked
options.B: Secured
options.C: Closed

en.description: When filling up a tanker with 3 or 4 bottom valves, make sure those valves are tightly shut. This prevents any spills or leaks while loading.

en.question: Why is it important to be aware of the required outage for the liquids you transport?

options.A: For some of the heaviest liquids, you don't need to leave any clearance.
options.B: Different liquids have the same outage requirements.
options.C: All liquids can be safely transported without considering outage.

en.description: Heavier liquids expand less, so they can often be filled to the top without risking overflow. Knowing each liquid's expansion needs helps prevent spills and ensures safe, efficient transportation.

en.question: Which of these facts is correct about how to steer in an emergency when driving a tanker?

options.A: You should only use one hand on the steering wheel during quick movements.
options.B: When making a quick steering movement, do not apply the brakes
options.C: Turning the steering wheel slowly is safer in emergencies.

en.description: When you need to steer quickly in a tanker, don't hit the brakes because it can lead to a skid or rollover. Quick and controlled steering is the way to prevent a crash without making things worse.

en.question: Empty trucks:

options.A: Are easier to control during sharp turns.
options.B: Can carry more weight than full trucks.
options.C: May require longer stopping distances than full ones

en.description: Empty trucks might take longer to stop than trucks full of stuff.

en.question: You have to be very careful when driving smooth bore tankers. This is even more important when you are:

options.A: Starting or stopping
options.B: While cruising at a steady speed
options.C: Driving in clear weather conditions

en.description: When driving trucks with smooth inner tanks, be extra careful, especially when starting or stopping. These actions can cause the liquid to move around a lot, making the truck hard to control.

en.question: What do you call the walls inside tanks that keep liquids from mixing together?

options.A: Bulkheads
options.B: Liquid holders
options.C: Liquid dividers

en.description: The correct answer is Bulkheads. These are walls inside tanks that keep different liquids apart so they don't mix. They make sure each section is sealed tight so nothing leaks from one compartment to another.

en.question: While driving a tank truck, if the front wheels start to skid, what is the most probable outcome?

options.A: You will continue in a straight line and keep moving forward no matter how much you steer
options.B: The truck will automatically correct itself and stop.
options.C: The truck will suddenly speed up.

en.description: If your tank truck's front wheels start skidding, you won't be able to steer it anymore. It'll just keep going straight, no matter how hard you try to turn the wheel.

en.question: Be very careful when driving smooth bore tankers, especially when:

options.A: Turning at an intersection.
options.B: Starting or stopping
options.C: When driving on flat, level highways

en.description: When driving trucks with smooth inner tanks, be extra careful, especially when starting or stopping. These actions can cause the liquid to move around a lot, making the truck hard to control.

en.question: What type of surge can occur in a tank equipped with baffles?

options.A: Side to side
options.B: Diagonal
options.C: Circular

en.question: How does liquid surge impact tanker truck driving?

options.A: Surge makes the fuel consumption more efficient.
options.B: Surge can move the truck in the direction the liquid waves move
options.C: Surge makes it easier to stop the truck quickly.

en.description: When liquid in a tanker moves back and forth, it can push the truck in the same direction. This makes driving and controlling the truck harder, especially when turning or stopping.

en.question: Why is it important to not steer too much, brake too hard, or speed up too quickly?

options.A: To avoid skids
options.B: To reduce fuel consumption.
options.C: To maintain tire pressure.

en.description: When you steer too much, brake too hard, or speed up too quickly, your vehicle can lose grip on the road, causing it to skid. Being gentle helps keep the vehicle stable and safe.

en.question: What braking technique should you use to prevent a sudden stop or collision?

options.A: Pump
options.B: Controlled or stab braking
options.C: Squeeze

en.description: Use 'controlled or stab braking' by pressing the brake hard until just before the wheels lock, then releasing and pressing again. This helps avoid losing control.

en.question: When navigating a curve with a tanker, the optimal approach is to decrease speed to a safe level before entering the curve, then ___ as you proceed through it.

options.A: Accelerate slightly
options.B: Maintain your speed.
options.C: Turn sharply.

en.description: Slow down before the curve, then gently accelerate through it to maintain stability and control.

en.question: Driving a truck with liquid tanks needs extra attention for two main reasons. One of the reasons is:

options.A: Liquid movement
options.B: Risk of spillage
options.C: High pressure buildup

en.description: The motion of the liquid can affect handling and stability, requiring extra care from the driver.

en.question: Which of the following statements accurately describes the relationship between speed and stopping distance?

options.B: Wet roads can double stopping distance at any speed
options.C: Higher tire pressure decreases stopping distance.

en.question: Baffles in tanks that carry liquid usually don't stop the sloshing of liquid from:

options.C: Back to front

en.question: When filling up the small tanks of a cargo tank equipped with bulkheads, you should check your:

options.A: The cargo will balance automatically without driver intervention.

options.C: The cargo will remain stationary at all times.

options.C: The truck will have increased side to side sway.

en.question: When filling up and emptying tanks with bulkheads, the driver needs to ensure the weight is evenly distributed.

options.A: TRUE
options.B: FALSE

en.description: Evenly distributing weight when filling or emptying tanks with bulkheads is essential for vehicle stability and safety.

en.question: During loading, what should be the position of the tankers' manhole covers and vent covers?

options.A: Loosely covered with cloth
options.B: Closed correctly.
options.C: Tightly sealed with tape

en.question: What should you inspect the tank's body or shell for?

options.A: Leaks and discoloration
options.B: Cracks and rust
options.C: Dents and leaks

en.question: Check special purpose equipment if your vehicle has any to make sure it:

options.A: Has enough fuel

options.C: Works.

en.description: Special equipment must be checked to ensure it functions properly, ensuring operational safety and reliability.

en.question: You do not have to check the pipe connections and hoses for leaks.

options.B: FALSE

en.question: How much liquid you can put in a tank depends on:

options.B: The legal weight limits
options.C: All answers are true

en.question: How far away should a helper stand when pumping or unloading liquids from a tanker?

options.B: Joints
options.C: Barriers

en.question: You must inspect a tanker before loading, unloading, or driving it to ensure it's safe for carrying liquid or gas and for driving.

options.B: FALSE

en.description: A full inspection is required before operating a tanker to ensure safety for both the driver and others on the road.

en.question: When encountering a situation where a tanker has lost its brakes, when should the driver consider using a truck escape ramp?

options.A: If the road is straight.

options.C: When the tank is empty.

en.question: What effect does the movement of liquid in partially filled tanks, known as liquid surge, have on the truck's handling?

options.A: Good effect
options.B: No effect
options.C: Bad effect

en.question: A tank vehicle is _

options.A: A vehicle designed exclusively for carrying solid materials.
options.B: A vehicle used to carry any liquid or liquid gas in a tank of 1000 gallons or more.
options.C: A vehicle with a large water tank used for firefighting purposes only.

en.question: What term describes the divisions between compartments inside tanks that have openings or holes in them?

options.A: Dividers
options.B: Baffles
options.C: Partitions

en.description: Baffles are special walls inside tank trucks with holes or openings. They help control the movement of liquids, making the vehicle easier to drive and safer on the road.

en.question: Transporting liquids in tank vehicles demands specific expertise because _.

options.A: Of the high center of gravity and liquid movement.
options.B: Because the tanks are often left empty.
options.C: Because the liquids can freeze and expand.

en.description: Driving a tank truck is tricky because the liquid inside moves around, making the truck harder to handle, and the truck is top-heavy which makes it easier to tip over.

en.question: While driving a tank truck, if the front wheels start skidding, what is the most probable outcome?

options.A: You will continue in a straight line and keep moving forward no matter how much you steer
options.B: The brakes will suddenly unlock by themselves.
options.C: The truck will automatically correct its course.

en.question: High center of gravity implies that a significant portion of the load's weight is positioned high above the road, resulting in the vehicle being:

options.A: Top heavy and easy to roll over.
options.B: Top heavy and more aerodynamic
options.C: Top heavy and faster on curves

en.question: When unloading the smaller tanks of a tank equipped with bulkheads, pay close attention to the:

options.A: Distribution of weight
