options.C: Temperature inside the tanks

en.description: When you empty smaller parts of a big tank, make sure the weight is spread out evenly. If not, it could be unsafe.

en.question: Some liquid tanks are divided into multiple smaller sections by dividers known as:

options.A: Sections
options.B: Bulkheads
options.C: Partitions

en.description: Bulkheads are like strong walls inside a liquid tank truck that divide it into smaller separate areas. This helps to keep the liquid stable and stops it from moving around too much when the truck is driving.

en.question: Tank vehicles must be inspected at specific times and come in various types and sizes. To ensure you know how to inspect your tank vehicle, you should:

options.A: Check with the last person that drove the vehicle.
options.B: Ask a friend who knows about trucks.
options.C: Check the vehicle's operator's manual.

en.description: To make sure you know how to check your tank vehicle properly, always refer to the vehicle's operator's manual. This manual has all the specific details and instructions you need for your particular vehicle.

en.question: On all tank vehicles the most important item to check is for:

options.A: Cracked hoses
options.B: Leaks
options.C: Broken seals

en.description: When checking tank vehicles, the most crucial thing to look for is leaks. This is because leaks can lead to loss of liquids, potentially causing accidents or environmental harm.

en.question: What do you call the walls inside a tanker that have holes at both the top and bottom?

options.A: Surfboards
options.B: Baffles
options.C: Partitions

en.description: The correct answer is baffles. These are like walls inside a tanker truck's tank with holes on the top and bottom. They help keep the liquid from moving around too much when the truck is turning or stopping, making the drive safer.

en.question: A smooth bore tank is __.

options.A: A liquid tank without baffles
options.B: A tank designed for compressed gases.
options.C: A dry bulk cargo tank

en.description: A smooth bore tank is a special kind of tank used to hold liquids. It's different because it doesn't have inside barriers, known as baffles, that usually help to keep the liquid from moving around too much.

en.question: Baffles in a tanker...

options.A: Help reduce the weight of the tanker
options.B: Control forward and backward liquid surge
options.C: Increase the speed of unloading liquids

en.description: Baffles in a tanker help control the liquid moving back and forth when the truck stops or starts. This makes driving safer by keeping the truck stable.

en.question: For what type of cargo is a liquid tank trailer without baffles typically used?

options.A: Milk or food products
options.B: Water for swimming pools
options.C: Chemicals for cleaning.

en.description: A liquid tank trailer without baffles is usually for carrying milk or food products. The sloshing is acceptable in these cases, unlike with more hazardous materials.

en.question: The driver needs to be extra careful with the _ on smaller tanks.

options.A: Higher center of gravity
options.B: Weight distribution
options.C: Level of fluid

en.description: When driving smaller tanks, it's important to watch out for a few things: how high the tank's center is, how its weight is spread out, and how much liquid is inside. All these can affect how safely you can drive.

en.question: How much liquid you can put in a tank depends on...

options.A: The amount of liquid expansion
options.B: The weight of the liquid
options.C: Legal weight limits

en.description: When filling a tank for a truck, consider how much the liquid can expand, the liquid's weight, and the maximum weight allowed by law. All these factors help decide how much liquid to safely load.

en.question: The cladding in a tanker...

options.A: Makes the tanker lighter.
options.B: Increases the tanker's speed.
options.C: Protects the tanker from corrosive cargo

en.description: Cladding acts as a barrier between the tanker's main structure and the corrosive substances it carries. This layer prevents direct contact with harmful chemicals, reducing damage and prolonging the tanker's service life.

en.question: What shape of tanker truck is the most stable?

options.A: Van
options.B: Rectangle
options.C: Cylindrical

en.description: The most stable shape for a tanker truck is elliptical. This shape helps the truck stay balanced and less likely to tip over when carrying liquids.

en.question: When driving around a curve, the most effective way to prevent a tanker from rolling over is to...

options.A: Travel at speeds below the posted limits
options.B: Keep the steering wheel straight.
options.C: Increase the weight of your cargo.

en.description: To avoid tipping over while driving a tanker around a turn, go slower than the speed signs suggest. This gives you more control and helps keep the truck stable.

en.question: A baffled tanker is one with...

options.A: Walls with holes inside the trailer for the liquid to flow through
options.B: Metal grids that absorb shocks.
options.C: A special coating that reduces liquid movement.

en.description: A baffled tanker has walls with holes inside the trailer. These holes let the liquid move slowly, making it safer and easier to control the tanker when it's moving.

en.question: It is not advisable to load a tank trailer completely full because _

options.A: It reduces the overall speed of the vehicle.
options.B: It increases fuel consumption significantly.
options.C: Liquid expands and can leak out of the trailer

en.description: When you fill a tank trailer all the way up, the liquid inside can get bigger when it gets warmer and might start leaking out. This is why you shouldn't load it completely full.

en.question: What makes driving a bulk liquid tanker so challenging?

options.A: The cargo's constant temperature
options.B: The cargo's solid state
options.C: The cargo's high center of gravity

en.description: Driving a bulk liquid tanker is challenging because the liquid moves around, creating a high center of gravity and shifting weight that makes the vehicle harder to control.

en.question: What term describes the movement of liquid in partially filled tanks?

options.A: Surging
options.B: Swirling
options.C: Rippling

en.description: When the tanks aren't full, the liquid inside moves back and forth strongly. This movement can affect how the vehicle drives. It's called 'surging.'

en.question: Outage means...

options.A: The process of liquid expansion as it becomes warm
options.B: The space needed for gas in a fully loaded fuel tanker.
options.C: The amount of fuel used during a trip.
options.D: The loss of headlights on the tractor

en.description: When liquids warm up, they expand and take up more space. 'Outage' describes this expansion and the allowance needed so the container doesn't overflow.

en.question: Drivers of tank trucks need special skills because...

options.A: The center of gravity is higher
options.B: The vehicle is top heavy
options.C: The load's weight is high up off the road

en.description: Tank truck drivers need special skills because these trucks have a higher center of gravity, are top-heavy, and the weight is high up off the road—making them prone to tipping.

en.question: How much liquid you should fill the tank with depends on...

options.A: The amount the liquid will expand in transit
options.B: The weight or density of the liquid
options.C: Legal weight limits

en.description: When filling a tank for transport, consider how much the liquid grows when moving, its weight or thickness, and the legal weight rules. All these factors help decide how much to load.

en.question: A tank trailer with baffles helps to control...

options.A: Tire pressure adjustments
options.B: Engine speed control
options.C: Movement from front to back

en.description: A tank trailer with baffles helps control front-to-back movement. Baffles are internal barriers that slow the liquid down, helping keep the vehicle stable.

en.question: The liquid in the bulk tank can make the tank truck tip over to the side...

options.A: When traveling around a curve
options.B: Even with baffles inside the trailer to slow flow
options.C: Even when traveling at posted speeds

en.description: The correct answer is 'All of the above.' Liquid movement can cause a tank truck to tip, even with baffles, during curves, or at posted speed limits.

en.question: You can minimize the impact of liquid surge if you...

options.A: Turn slowly and carefully
options.B: Gradually brake to a stop
options.C: Haul thicker liquids

en.description: To avoid the effects of liquid surge, turn slowly, brake gently, and haul thicker liquids. These steps all help maintain better control.

en.question: When driving, it's important to pay attention to the speed limits for curves and understand that...

options.A: Tank trucks have a higher center of gravity
options.B: The posted speeds may not be slow enough for a tank truck
options.C: A rollover can still occur when traveling at posted speeds in a tank truck

en.description: The correct answer is 'All of the above.' Tank trucks are more prone to rollovers even at posted speeds due to their higher center of gravity and sensitivity to curves.

en.question: Stop valves in a cargo tank...

options.A: Are controlled remotely
options.B: Close in an emergency
options.C: Open automatically during maintenance
options.D: Protect the tank and piping from rear end collisions

en.description: Stop valves in a cargo tank are special parts that automatically close in an emergency to prevent spills.

en.question: In what situations should you exercise extra caution when driving a smooth bore tanker combination?

options.A: While ascending a hill
options.B: While descending a hill
options.C: When starting and stopping

en.description: Be very careful when starting or stopping a smooth bore tanker. The liquid can move around a lot, making the truck harder to control.

en.question: How does liquid surge affect driving a tanker?

options.A: Surge can move the truck in the direction the liquid waves move
options.B: Surge helps the truck maintain a steady speed on hills.
options.C: Surge makes it easier to speed up and slow down.

en.description: When liquid in a tanker moves back and forth, it can push the truck in that direction, making control harder, especially when stopping or turning.

en.question: How do you think a truck carrying a tank with partitions inside would drive on the road?

options.A: There will be less front to back surge than there is in a tanker without baffles
options.B: The truck will have increased fuel efficiency.
options.C: The truck's speed will automatically adjust to road conditions.

en.description: A truck with baffles in the tank experiences less sloshing, making it more stable than a tanker without baffles.

en.question: When you fill up the small tanks inside a big tank that has dividers, you should check your:

options.A: Engine temperature
options.B: Weight distribution
options.C: Tire pressure

en.description: Check weight distribution when filling small tanks inside a big tank. This keeps the vehicle balanced and safe on the road.

en.question: Before loading, unloading, or moving the vehicle, ensure that the _ is/are positioned correctly.

options.A: Intake valve
options.B: Discharge valve
options.C: Cut-off valve

en.description: Before handling the load, check that the intake, discharge, and cut-off valves are all in the right position for safety and function.

en.question: When driving trucks with smooth inside tanks, you need to be very careful, especially when you are:

options.A: While cruising at a steady speed
options.B: When shifting gears during transit
options.C: Starting or stopping

en.description: Smooth tanks allow liquid to move more freely. This is especially risky when starting or stopping, as the surge can make the truck unstable.

en.question: When driving on a clear night and dimming your headlights from high to low, what distance should you be able to stop within?

options.A: The distance you can see ahead
options.B: The time it takes to sing the 'Happy Birthday' song twice.
options.C: Twice the length of an Olympic swimming pool

en.description: At night, always ensure you can stop within the distance your low-beam headlights let you see. This helps prevent accidents in low visibility.

en.question: Hauling liquids in tankers requires special care for two reasons. One reason is the _ center of gravity that tankers have.

options.A: Shallow
options.B: Flat
options.C: Low

en.description: Liquid tankers have a high center of gravity. This makes them more prone to tipping and requires careful handling during turns and stops.

en.question: When your truck has baffles, how will it affect your driving?

options.A: The vehicle will use more fuel.
options.B: The cargo will settle more evenly during long trips.
options.C: There will be less front to back surge than there is in tanks without baffles

en.description: Baffles in a cargo tank help control the movement of liquid so it doesn't slosh front to back as much. This makes your truck easier and safer to handle.

en.question: You need to be aware of the space left empty for the liquids you transport because:

options.A: Some liquids expand more than others when they get warm
options.B: Tank baffles are not always legal with outage
options.C: Some of the heaviest liquids do not need any

en.description: Liquids expand when warmed. Knowing this helps ensure you leave enough space in the tank to prevent overfilling or spills.

en.question: If a tanker's brakes stop working, when is it okay for the driver to use a truck escape ramp?

options.A: Only when driving downhill.
options.B: Always
options.C: If the weather is clear and sunny.
options.D: Only if the tank is empty

en.description: If your tanker's brakes fail, use a truck escape ramp whenever needed, especially on downgrades. It’s designed for emergencies.

en.question: Side to side surge can result in:

options.A: Brake failure
options.B: Tire blowout
options.C: Roll over

en.description: Sudden liquid movement from side to side can cause a tanker to roll over. It’s a major stability risk that drivers must manage carefully.

en.question: Baffles in liquid cargo tanks typically do not prevent the surge movement from:

options.A: Front to back
options.B: Top to bottom
options.C: Side to side

en.description: Baffles reduce front to back movement of liquid but don’t help much with side to side movement, which can still affect handling.

en.question: Which of these statements accurately describes emergency steering with tankers?

options.A: Turn off your engine before starting a quick steering movement.
options.B: When making a quick steering movement, do not apply the brakes
options.C: You should increase your speed before starting a quick steering movement.

en.description: Avoid braking during quick steering in a tanker. Applying brakes while steering suddenly can destabilize the truck.

en.question: Retest markings...

options.A: Display the tank's manufacturer.
options.B: Indicate the color of the tank.
options.C: Show what type of test or inspection was performed

en.description: Retest markings show what kind of test or inspection was performed on a tank to confirm it meets safety standards.

en.question: What is an outage?

options.A: Volume of the container
options.B: Space in the tank for air
options.C: Allowance for expansion of liquid

en.description: Outage is the extra space left in the tank to allow the liquid to expand when it warms up. It prevents overflow and damage.

en.question: The safest way to drive a tanker around a curve is to slow down to a safe speed before you start turning, then — while you're in the curve.

options.A: Keep your speed constant.
options.B: Accelerate slightly
options.C: Turn sharply.

en.description: Before a curve, slow to a safe speed. Then, slightly accelerate through the curve to maintain stability and control.

en.question: You should be very careful when you drive tankers with smooth insides. This is even more important when you are:

options.A: Parking on a hill.
options.B: Starting or stopping
options.C: Driving on a straight road

en.description: Smooth tanks allow liquid to move freely, especially when starting or stopping. This can make the truck harder to control.

en.question: A tank vehicle is a vehicle used for carrying...

options.A: Liquid
options.B: Liquified gas
options.C: Frozen goods

en.description: A tank vehicle is used to carry liquids and liquified gases. It is not used to transport frozen goods.

en.question: When you're driving a big truck with a tank and the front wheels start sliding, what's probably going to happen?

options.A: The brakes will lock up, causing a sudden stop.
options.B: The truck will automatically correct its path.
options.C: You will continue in a straight line and keep moving forward no matter how much you steer

en.description: If your tank truck’s front wheels start to slide, you lose steering control and the truck will keep moving straight.

en.question: What do you call the walls inside tanks that stop liquids from mixing together?

options.A: Bulkheads
options.B: Partition walls
options.C: Liquid locks

en.description: Bulkheads are solid walls inside a tank that keep different liquids from mixing and help stabilize the tank.

en.question: In the scenario where a bulk tank vehicle is stopping at a slippery intersection, what potential risk might occur?

options.A: The driver might lose control due to decreased visibility.
options.B: The liquid movement could push the truck into the intersection
options.C: Stopping too quickly may cause a skid.
options.D: The truck could slide sideways due to rocking

en.description: When stopping on a slippery surface, the moving liquid inside can create forward force, pushing the truck into the intersection.

en.question: What is the primary cause that could lead to a rollover of a baffled tank?

options.A: Uneven tire pressure
options.B: Side-to-side liquid surge
options.C: Improper loading of cargo

en.description: Side-to-side liquid movement, even in baffled tanks, can create a rollover risk if not carefully managed.

en.question: Which of these items would be classified as special equipment for tankers?

options.A: Vapor recovery kits
options.B: Pressure monitoring systems
options.C: Liquid level gauges

en.description: Vapor recovery kits are special safety equipment used to capture vapors during loading/unloading of liquids in tankers.

en.question: In what situations should you exercise extra caution when driving a smooth bore tanker combination?

options.A: While ascending a hill
options.B: While descending a hill
options.C: When starting and stopping

en.description: Smooth bore tanks allow more liquid surge. Extra caution is needed during starts and stops to maintain control.

en.question: Which of the following statements regarding the converter dolly uncoupling is true?

options.A: Lower the landing gear before disconnecting the air lines.
options.B: Do not unlock the pintle hook while the dolly is still under the rear trailer.
options.C: Ensure the dolly wheels are fully inflated before uncoupling.

en.description: Never unlock the pintle hook while the dolly is still under the trailer, to prevent unexpected movement and accidents.

en.question: When coupling twin/double trailers, if the rear trailer does not have spring brakes, ___?

options.A: Ensure the service line is blocked before coupling.
options.B: The emergency line should be connected and disconnected to set the emergency brakes.
options.C: Make sure the service line is empty before coupling.

en.description: To set the emergency brakes on a trailer without spring brakes, connect and disconnect the emergency line to pressurize and then lock the brakes.

en.question: Which statement regarding space management when operating double or triple trailers is incorrect?

options.A: The trailers automatically adjust to traffic speed.
options.B: Double trailers can be parked in compact car spaces.
options.C: They do not need more space when turning or stopping.

en.description: Double/triple trailers need more space to turn and stop, making this statement incorrect.

en.question: Which statement accurately describes the process of coupling second and third trailers?

options.A: Coupling second and third trailers requires several fewer steps than when coupling doubles.
options.B: The converter dolly is not used.
options.C: Coupling second and third trailers is the same as coupling doubles.

en.description: The procedure for coupling second and third trailers is the same as for coupling doubles, with similar alignment and connection steps.

en.question: What sign shows that converter dollies made after March 1998 have antilock brakes?

options.A: A red lamp on the top of the dolly.
options.B: A red lamp at the back of the dolly.
options.C: A yellow lamp on the left side of the dolly

en.question: Why should you maneuver the steering wheel with smooth and gradual movements, avoiding abrupt or jerky turns when driving a double/triple trailer?

options.A: It helps the trailers stay in a straight line during high winds.
options.B: It makes it easier to control the speed of your trailers.
options.C: Steering gently helps to prevent the crack-the-whip effect.

en.description: Smooth steering reduces the risk of the 'crack-the-whip' effect, which can cause trailers to roll over.

en.question: Which statement regarding shutoff valves in double/triple trailers is false?

options.A: The valves in the rear of the front trailer should be closed.
options.B: The valves in the middle trailer should always be partially open.
options.C: The valves on the side of the middle trailer should be open.

en.description: The shutoff valves at the rear of the front trailer should be open to allow air to reach the rear trailers.

en.question: At what point during the uncoupling of the rear trailer should you place a wheel chock?

options.A: After releasing converter dolly brakes
options.B: If it doesn't have spring brakes
options.C: After disconnecting dolly air and electric lines

en.description: If the trailer does not have spring brakes, wheel chocks should be used to prevent movement during uncoupling.

en.question: Which of the following actions is not part of the process when uncoupling a converter dolly?

options.A: Applying the converter gear spring brakes or wheel chocks
options.B: Connecting safety chains
options.C: Lowering landing gear

en.description: Safety chains are connected during coupling, not uncoupling. The other steps are part of safe uncoupling.

en.question: What additional action is required when inspecting the brakes on a double or triple trailer, which isn't necessary for other types of combination vehicles?

options.A: None; the steps for checking the brakes are the same for both combination and double/triple trailers.
options.B: Inspect the suspension system.
options.C: Inspect the tire tread depth.

en.description: Brake inspections are the same for double/triple trailers and other combination vehicles.

en.question: Anti Lock brakes are standard on converter dollies manufactured after March 1998. You can identify them by the presence of ___?

options.A: A blue lamp on the front of the dolly.
options.B: A green lamp on the top of the dolly.
options.C: A yellow lamp on the left side of the dolly

en.description: Converter dollies built after March 1998 with ABS feature a yellow lamp on the left side to indicate antilock brakes.

en.question: What measures can be taken to avoid rollovers while operating double/triple trailers?

options.A: Go slowly around corners.
options.B: Use higher gears on declines.
options.C: Drive fast in high winds.

en.description: Taking turns slowly and carefully helps prevent rollover accidents, especially in long or multi-trailer vehicles.

en.question: What statement accurately describes driving double/triple trailers in slippery conditions?

options.A: They have more dead axles to pull, which can cause loss of traction.
options.B: They can easily navigate tight turns without any risk.
options.C: They require less stopping distance than single trailers.

en.question: Which statement regarding coupling and uncoupling various trailer combinations is inaccurate?

options.A: There is only one way to couple and uncouple different trailer combinations.
options.B: One should couple and uncouple different trailer combinations according to the manufacturer or owner's directions.
options.C: Uncoupling tractor trailers can be dangerous if not done correctly.

en.description: There is not a single universal way to couple and uncouple trailers—always follow the specific procedures outlined for each configuration.

en.question: What safety measure is advisable for handling trucks and semitrailers?

options.A: The heaviest semitrailer should be behind the truck.
options.B: The tractor should be driven faster than the semitrailer to ensure stability.
options.C: Always disconnect the air lines before backing up.

en.question: Which of the following actions is not part of the process when coupling double trailers?

options.A: Release the dolly brakes.
options.B: Put the converter dolly in front of the second (rear) trailer.
options.C: Put the converter dolly behind the rear trailer.

en.question: Which statement correctly reflects the handling of double/triple trailers?

options.A: They need more space when turning or stopping
options.B: Double/triple trailers can easily navigate through sharp turns at high speeds.
options.C: Double/triple trailers do not require CDL to operate.

en.description: These types of trailers are longer and require more space to safely turn and come to a stop.

en.question: Which statement regarding the uncoupling of a rear trailer is true?

options.A: When on firm ground, park the rig straight.
options.B: Always disconnect the electrical lines before the air lines.
options.C: Ensure the air lines are disconnected before the electrical lines.

en.description: A level, straight position on firm ground provides the safest conditions for uncoupling a rear trailer.

en.question: What should be the primary concern when parking a double/triple trailer?

options.A: Making sure your trailer covers two parking spaces for visibility.
options.B: Making sure you are aligned with the sun to avoid glare.
options.C: Parking in a spot that gives you the ability to pull through

en.description: Choosing a spot that allows a pull-through exit reduces the need to back up, increasing safety and ease of departure.

en.question: Which action should not be performed when uncoupling a rear trailer?

options.A: Close air shutoffs in the rear of the first semitrailer.
options.B: Release dolly brakes.
options.C: Tighten converter dolly fifth wheel latch.

en.description: Releasing the dolly brakes during uncoupling can allow the trailer to move, which is dangerous. Keep the brakes applied.

en.question: To ensure proper air flow to all trailers in double and triple rigs, what should you do after applying air to the service line?

options.A: Go to the rear trailer, open the emergency line shut-off valve and listen for air escaping.
options.B: Disconnect the service line and observe for air pressure loss.
options.C: Check the tire pressure on the second trailer.

en.question: At what air pressure range does a truck protection valve automatically close to prevent air from escaping the truck?

options.A: 20 PSI to 45 PSI
options.B: 30 PSI to 70 PSI
options.C: 70 PSI to 80 PSI

en.question: You are operating a triple trailer, and suddenly the emergency brakes for all three trailers engage. What caused it?

options.A: The emergency line has lost air pressure.
options.B: The service brake pedal is stuck.
options.C: The trailers are not properly connected.

en.question: Which statement is false regarding loading cargo into double/triple trailers?

options.A: Cargo that is not centered in the trailer has little impact on the rig.
options.B: Keep cargo as close to the ground as possible in all trailers.
options.C: Keep cargo close to the ground to lower the center of gravity.

en.description: Uncentered cargo can make a trailer unstable and increase the risk of tipping or loss of control. The claim that it has little impact is false.

en.question: Which of the following is a step/recommendation to follow when uncoupling a converter dolly on a twin trailer rig?

options.A: Never unlock the pintle hook with the dolly still under the rear trailer.
options.B: Be sure the dolly is under the rear trailer when unlocking the pintle hook.
options.C: Raise the dolly landing gear.

en.question: What is the primary reason for dedicating more time to examining a double or triple rig?

options.A: They are more difficult to drive in bad weather.
options.B: There are more parts to check and more things that can go wrong.
options.C: It takes more time to fuel up.

en.question: Which part of a double/triple trailer is most susceptible to turning over due to the 'crack-the-whip' effect?

options.A: The middle trailer in a triple setup
options.B: The front of the truck

en.question: What should you do first if your vehicle starts to jackknife?

options.A: Steer sharply to the left.
options.B: Ease up on the brakes so you can get your traction back.
options.C: Turn the steering wheel rapidly back and forth.

options.B: Foot pedal
options.C: The parking brake

en.question: What could potentially lead to a jackknife scenario while driving a double trailer?

options.A: You accelerated smoothly in a straight line.
options.B: A set of trailer wheels has gone into a skid
options.C: The road is perfectly dry and straight.

en.question: Why is it important to inspect the fifth wheel on a double/triple trailer setup?

options.A: It reduces fuel consumption.
options.B: It ensures proper coupling and trailer attachment.
options.C: It regulates brake pressure.

en.question: Which component connects a converter dolly to a trailer?

options.B: Drawbar eye
options.C: Pintle hook

en.question: What is the purpose of checking glad hands during inspection?

options.A: To ensure proper tire inflation
options.B: To verify electrical conductivity
options.C: To check for air leaks and secure connection

en.question: What risk increases if trailers are not properly balanced in weight distribution?

options.A: Fuel efficiency improves
options.B: Risk of trailer jackknifing or tipping increases
options.C: Brakes last longer

en.question: When inspecting the trailer service line, what should you check?

options.C: Brake pad thickness

en.question: What’s a key reason for performing a tug test on each connection in a double or triple trailer?

options.C: To verify headlight function

en.question: What should be done before disconnecting the rear trailer of a double or triple setup?

options.B: Rev the engine

en.question: When conducting a walkaround inspection, why is it important to check the converter dolly?

options.C: To confirm fuel levels

en.question: What does a double trailer rig require during a pre-trip inspection that a single rig might not?

options.B: Inspection of the coupling systems between trailers
options.C: Fuel cap security

en.question: When coupling a second trailer to your combination vehicle, what should you use to secure it?

options.B: Wheel chocks

options.B: FALSE

options.C: Counter steer and accelerate

en.question: How do you know that the trailer height is correct before attaching a converter dolly to a second or third trailer?

en.question: What purpose does a converter dolly serve?

en.question: A combination vehicle requires a more extensive inspection compared to a single vehicle?

options.A: TRUE
options.B: FALSE

options.B: Trailer air balance lever
options.C: Air pressure adjustment knob

en.question: What precaution should you take when making a turn with a double or triple?

options.A: Turn wide enough to avoid the curb or pedestrians but, at the same time, not too wide so that a driver can try to pass you on the right.
options.B: Make sharp turns to keep all trailers aligned.
options.C: Turn wide enough to avoid the curb.

en.question: Under what circumstances could a drive-wheel skid while pulling doubles lead to a jackknife?

en.question: What is a correct procedure for uncoupling a rear trailer?

options.A: When on firm ground, park the rig straight.

options.C: Always disconnect the air lines before lowering the landing gear.

en.question: What are three ways to make sure a second trailer is safely attached before linking it up?

options.B: Wheel the dolly into position by hand so it is in line with the kingpin.

en.question: Do all converter dollies come with spring brakes?

options.A: Yes
options.B: No

en.question: Is it necessary to conduct a walk-around inspection before pulling doubles or triples?

options.A: Yes
options.B: No

en.description: A thorough walk-around inspection is essential to ensure all parts of doubles or triples are safe and ready for the road.

en.question: Two different methods are used for uncoupling the second and third trailers.

options.B: FALSE

options.A: TRUE
options.B: FALSE

en.description: While standard procedures apply to typical combinations, various trailer setups may require different techniques.

en.question: Many large trucks are equipped with convex, or "spot," mirrors. These mirrors __

options.A: Can only be used at night.

en.question: Once the rear truck is correctly connected to the converter dolly, ___

en.question: What precautions should be taken when connecting the converter dolly to the rear trailer?

options.A: Make sure trailer brakes are locked
options.B: Make sure trailer height is correct

en.description: All these steps—locking trailer brakes, ensuring correct height, and slightly raising the landing gear—are necessary for safely connecting the converter dolly.

en.question: To prevent which potential issue should you assess your truck protection valve?

options.A: The emergency brakes coming on due to loss of air

options.C: The loss of air from your trailer brakes

en.description: Assessing the truck protection valve prevents multiple air system failures, including emergency brake engagement and trailer brake air loss.

en.question: When maneuvering to evade a collision with double trailers while pulling doubles, remember to __

options.A: Keep both hands on the steering wheel
options.B: Stay off the brake while turning
options.C: Be prepared to counter-steer

en.description: All listed actions—steady steering, avoiding braking mid-turn, and counter-steering—are key to safely avoiding collisions with doubles.

en.question: When operating triple trailers, which part is at a higher risk of rolling over?

options.A: The second trailer
options.B: The middle trailer
options.C: The last trailer

en.question: Is it advisable to release the pintle hook while the converter dolly remains under a trailer?

options.B: Yes, this keeps the trailer from falling

en.question: When connecting twin trailers, you should disengage the dolly brakes by __

options.D: Pushing the air release valve on the dash

en.question: To begin coupling doubles, start by__

options.A: Lowering the landing gear on the first trailer fully.

en.question: Trucks with double or triple trailers...

options.A: Have a dangerous 'crack the whip' effect
options.B: Present a rearward amplification hazard
options.C: Can turn over in response to abrupt steering movements

en.description: Double and triple trailer trucks are subject to all listed hazards—whip effect, amplification, and rollovers from sharp steering.

en.question: When uncoupling double trailers, where should you park your rig?

options.A: Near a water body
options.B: On level ground
options.C: Near a loading dock

en.description: Always park on level ground when uncoupling double trailers to ensure safety and stability.

en.question: During an inspection of doubles, what should be the position of the shut-off valves at the rear of a trailer?

en.question: During a walk-around inspection of a double or triple trailer rig, you should ensure the converter dolly air tank drain valves are __ and the pintle hook is __

options.A: Closed, locked.
options.B: Closed, unlocked
options.C: Closed, latched

en.description: When checking a big truck with two or three trailers, make sure the air tank valves under the trailers are shut tight and the hook connecting the trailers is securely latched.

en.question: Which part of a truck-trailer combination is most prone to rolling over due to the "crack the whip" effect?

options.A: The rear trailer of a double
options.B: A full trailer behind a truck
options.C: The rear trailer of a triple

So, the rear trailer of a triple is most at risk, especially compared to just one trailer, no matter the weather.

en.question: Under what circumstances does the "driver's manual" recommend disengaging the steering axle brakes to maintain the vehicle's straight path?

options.A: Before going uphill.
options.B: When making a tight turn.
options.C: When the road is slippery

en.question: When driving a 100-foot truck with double trailers at 30 mph on a dry road with good visibility, ensure you maintain a distance of at least __ seconds ahead.
en.description: To drive a big truck with two trailers safely at 30 mph on a dry road, you should keep a distance of at least 10 seconds ahead of you. This helps ensure there's enough space to stop or slow down if needed.

en.question: When operating a truck with double or triple trailers, what actions should a driver take?

options.A: Use special care in bad weather and mountain conditions
options.B: Allow more following distance than for smaller vehicles
options.C: Both A and B

This helps to prevent accidents because these conditions can make driving more dangerous. This extra space allows more time to stop or react if something unexpected happens.

en.question: When hauling multiple trailers, which trailer should be positioned directly behind the truck?

options.A: The oldest trailer
options.B: The heaviest trailer
options.C: The newest trailer

en.description: When pulling more than one trailer, the heaviest trailer should be directly behind the truck. This helps keep the drive smoother and safer.

en.question: How should you handle a skid to stop it?

options.A: Turn off the engine.
options.B: Countersteer and accelerate
options.C: Restore traction to the tires

en.description: To stop a skid, make sure the tires can grip the road again. Do this by steering gently in the direction you want to go and avoid braking hard.

en.question: Which statement accurately describes the relationship between quick steering movements and double/triple trailers?

options.A: Using cruise control is recommended for stability during quick steering moves.
options.B: Doubles / triples are no problem with a quick steering move
options.C: Quick steering movements increase stability for double and triple trailers.
options.D: Doubles / triples flip over from quick steering moves more easily than many other vehicles

en.description: When you make a rapid turn with a vehicle pulling two or three trailers, it's easier for those trailers to tip over compared to other types of vehicles. Be extra careful with quick steering.

en.question: When driving with double trailers and faced with the need to brake suddenly to prevent a collision, what action should you take for emergency braking?

options.A: Pump the brakes lightly and repeatedly.
options.B: Use only the trailer brakes
options.C: Use controlled or stab braking

en.description: If you're driving a truck with two trailers and need to stop quickly to avoid an accident, the best way to brake is to use controlled or stab braking. en.question: The shippers package hazardous materials, they must certify that this was done according to the regulations. The only exception is when:

options.A: The shipper is a private carrier carrying his or her own product
options.B: The shipment is a hazardous waste
options.C: The driver is given a sealed cargo compartment

en.description: When companies send out dangerous goods, they must follow rules to pack them safely. The only time they don't have to is if the company is moving its own products and not selling the service.

en.question: With most hazardous materials, you may park within 5 feet of the road briefly. If your work requires it. The materials that are the exception and do not allow parking this close to the road are?

options.A: Explosives 1.1 thru 1.3
options.B: Corrosives and oxidizers
options.C: Acids and poisons

en.description: When it comes to parking near the road with hazardous materials, you usually can if it's quick and needed for work. But, don't do this with very explosive materials (like fireworks or dynamite), flammable stuff (like gasoline or propane), because it's too dangerous.

en.question: By law, how regularly must employees involved in transporting hazardous materials be tested?

options.B: At least every 5 years
options.C: Within 90 days of hire and then every 3 years

en.question: How do you gain a hazardous material endorsement?

options.A: Pass a written test on the regulations and requirements.
options.B: Apply for the endorsement and pay the associated fee.
options.C: You must have been transporting hazardous materials for at least 5 years.

en.description: To get permission to carry dangerous goods, you must pass a written exam about the rules and what you need to do.

en.question: What forms can hazardous materials come in?

options.A: Gases, solids, and flammable and combustible liquids
options.B: Solids, gases, and combustible liquids
options.C: Gases and combustible liquids

en.description: Hazardous materials can be in different forms like gases (air-like materials), solids (hard or powdery substances), and liquids that can catch fire easily or burn slowly. These materials need special care when being moved to keep everyone safe.

en.question: When there is a hazardous materials emergency. You should:

options.A: Keep people away and warn them of the danger
options.B: Prevent smoking and keep open flames away
options.C: Both

en.description: In a hazardous materials emergency, it is important to both keep people away and warn them of the danger, as well as prevent smoking and keep open flames away. en.question: What is the Reportable Quantity of phosphoric acid?

options.A: 100 Pounds
options.C: 5000 Pounds

options.B: Oxidizers
options.C: Both

en.question: When fueling a placarded vehicle, someone must always be:

en.question: What does ERG stand for?

options.B: Explosive Risk Guidelines
options.C: Emergency Response Guidebook

en.question: The emergency response telephone number is the responsibility of which individual?

options.C: The carrier

options.C: Phorate

en.question: Which of the following is the most important package marking?

en.question: When is it necessary to ground the trailer?

options.B: Only when unloading a cargo tank filled with any flammable liquid
options.C: When filling or unloading any flammable liquid tank, ground must be maintained until filling hole is properly closed

en.question: What type fire extinguisher is required in the power unit of a placarded vehicle?

options.B: A U.L. rating of 5 B:C or above
options.C: A U.L. rating of 15 ABC

options.B: A bulk container not permanently attached to a vehicle
options.C: Both

en.question: What does an orange placard represent?

options.C: Explosive contents

options.B: The explosives have been placed at least 200 feet away from the vehicles and occupied buildings

options.B: Check for a fence around the loading dock
options.C: Look at the shipping papers

en.question: Who is responsible for checking to be sure the shipper correctly named, labeled, and marked a hazardous materials shipment?

en.question: A truck has hazardous material, when can it be moved without the placards on the truck?

en.question: In what order are proper shipping names listed in the hazardous materials table?

en.question: Whose responsibility is it to package the hazardous product correctly?

options.A: In an emergency situation
options.B: When the fire department is there
options.C: You should never make a transfer

en.description: Transfers between tankers on public roadways are only allowed in emergency situations where safety is at risk.

en.question: A vehicle contains 500 pounds each of explosives 1.1 and 1.3, you must use:

options.A: explosives 1.1 placards
options.B: dangerous placards
options.C: blasting agents placards

en.description: When carrying 500 pounds or more of explosives 1.1 and 1.3, the vehicle must display 'explosives 1.1' placards.

en.question: What does 'RQ' stand for?

options.A: Regulated Quality
options.B: Reduced Quality
options.C: Reportable Quantity

en.description: RQ stands for Reportable Quantity, which means the amount of hazardous substance that requires reporting if released.

en.question: Which hazard class does sodium come under?

options.A: Flammable liquid
options.B: Spontaneously combustible when wet
options.C: Spontaneously combustible

en.description: Sodium reacts violently with water and can ignite on contact. It's classified under materials that are spontaneously combustible when wet.

en.question: In the hazardous material table, column 3, any shipping name written in italics means?

options.A: Just another way of writing the shipping name
options.B: That this substance is highly flammable
options.C: It isn't the proper shipping name, those in roman type above it are

en.description: Italicized names in the hazardous materials table are not proper shipping names. Use the non-italicized (roman type) names listed above them.

en.question: What action should you take if you see the phrase "Inhalation Hazard" on your shipping paper?

options.A: Ensure good ventilation.
options.B: Display "poison" or "poison gas" placard.
options.C: Display a Class 5 placard.

en.description: If your shipping papers say "Inhalation Hazard," you must display a placard that says 'Poison' or 'Poison Gas' to warn of breathing dangers.

en.question: Which of these is not a responsibility of the driver?

options.A: Follow all rules about transporting hazardous materials.
options.B: Deny leaking shipments.
options.C: Decide the identification number of the product.

en.description: The shipper is responsible for assigning the correct identification number. The driver follows regulations and checks for safety.

en.question: The total transport index of all radioactive material packages in a single vehicle must not exceed -
en.description: The transport index is a number that shows radiation levels. The total must not go over 50 per vehicle for safety.

en.question: If there is an RQ before or after the item description on the shipping paper, it means the:

options.A: Material has an insurance value of over $1,000
options.B: Material is in a package containing no other materials
options.C: Carrier must report any spill of this material

en.description: RQ means 'Reportable Quantity.' If spilled, it must be reported to proper authorities because it could pose a hazard.

en.question: What three things do you need to know to decide which placards (if any) you need?

options.A: Amount of all hazardous material on your truck, the weight of the material, the color of the material.
options.B: What you were told is on the truck, the amount of material on the truck, material's hazard class.
options.C: Material's hazard class, amount being shipped, amount of all hazardous material on your truck.

en.description: To pick the correct placards, you must know the hazard class, the amount you're shipping, and the total of all hazardous materials onboard.

en.question: What information must be shown on a hazardous materials shipping paper, and in what order?

options.A: Proper shipping name, packing group, ID number, hazard class
options.B: ID number, proper shipping name, hazard class, packing group
options.C: Hazard class, proper shipping name, ID number, packing group

en.description: Hazardous materials shipping papers must list in order: ID number, proper shipping name, hazard class, and packing group.

en.question: Drivers placard their vehicle to __ the risk.

options.A: Stop
options.B: Minimize
options.C: Show

en.description: Placards are used to **show** that the vehicle contains hazardous materials. This alerts others to the risk for safety purposes.

en.question: Who is responsible for signing the shipping documents for hazardous materials?

options.A: The driver hauling the hazardous materials.
options.B: The shipper packaging the hazardous materials.
options.C: The owner of the truck hauling the materials.

en.description: The shipper is responsible for properly preparing and signing the shipping documents for hazardous materials before transport.

en.question: What are cargo tanks?

options.A: Tanks that are not permanently attached to a vehicle.
options.B: Tanks that are put on the vehicle for transportation.
options.C: Tanks that remain on the vehicle when you load and unload them.

en.description: Cargo tanks are special tanks that stay on the vehicle while loading and unloading. They are used to transport liquids or gases and are not removed from the truck.

en.question: In what order do the following operate?

options.A: Carrier, driver, shipper
options.B: Shipper, driver, carrier
options.C: Shipper, carrier, driver

en.description: First, the shipper prepares the shipment. Then the carrier takes responsibility for transport. Finally, the driver physically moves the goods. The correct order is shipper, carrier, driver.

en.question: Around which hazard classes must you never smoke?

options.A: Class 1 explosives, class 4 flammable solids, class 5 oxidizers, class 3 flammable liquids
options.B: Class 8 explosives, class 6 flammable solids, class 7 explosives, class 5 flammable solids
options.C: Class 1 through 5 flammable liquids

en.description: Smoking is not allowed near materials that are explosive, flammable, or can help other materials burn faster. These include Class 1, 3, 4, and 5 hazardous materials.

en.question: Which three hazard classes should not be loaded into a trailer that has a heater or air conditioner unit?

options.A: Class 4 explosives, class 1 oxidizer, class 8 flammable solid
options.B: Class 1 explosives, class 4 flammable solids, class 5 oxidizers
options.C: Class 1 flammable solid, class 2 flammable solid, class 3 flammable solid

en.description: Explosives (Class 1), flammable solids (Class 4), and oxidizers (Class 5) should not be in trailers with temperature control units, which could trigger combustion.

en.question: Shippers package in order to the material__

options.A: Safely ship
options.B: Quickly ship
options.C: Cheaply ship

en.description: Shippers package goods to make sure they’re transported safely and arrive undamaged. Safety is always the main goal.

en.question: What is a portable tank?

options.A: Tanks that are permanently attached to a vehicle.
options.B: Tanks that are not permanently attached to a vehicle and are loaded and unloaded while the tank is off the vehicle.
options.C: Tanks that are sometimes attached and sometimes not attached to a vehicle

en.description: Portable tanks can be removed from a vehicle and are usually filled or emptied when not on the truck. They’re not permanently attached.

en.question: What is shipper's certification?

options.A: Certifies that the package has been prepared according to the rules.
options.B: Certifies that the materials have been paid for.
options.C: Certifies that the driver has a CDL with Hazardous Material Endorsement.

en.description: The shipper’s certification is a statement that the package was prepared and labeled according to legal and safety rules.

en.question: Where must you keep shipping papers describing hazardous materials?

options.A: In the tool storage area.
options.B: In the driver's wallet.
options.C: In the cab of the tractor driver door or in view within immediate reach.

en.description: Shipping papers for hazardous materials must be kept in the truck cab, either on the driver's door or where they can be quickly reached and seen.

en.question: An order contains both hazardous and nonhazardous materials. Which of the following is not an appropriate way marking the hazardous materials on the shipping paper?

options.A: The letters "NHM" in the column "HM."
options.B: Highlighted in a contrasting color.
options.C: The letter "X" or "RQ" in a column marked "HM."

en.description: "NHM" stands for non-hazardous material and should not be used to mark hazardous goods. Use an "X," "RQ," or highlight to mark hazardous items properly.

en.question: What must a driver have before transporting hazardous materials?

options.A: A CDL with a HazMat endorsement
options.B: A safety inspection report
options.C: An escort vehicle

en.description: Drivers must have a Commercial Driver’s License (CDL) with a Hazardous Materials (HazMat) endorsement to legally and safely transport hazardous materials.
